books.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 1

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 1:1
verses.text: The Stromata, or Miscellanies  Book 6  Chapter I.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 1:2
verses.text: —Plan.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 1:3
verses.text: The sixth and also the seventh Miscellany of gnostic notes, in accordance with the true philosophy, having delineated as well as possible the ethical argument conveyed in them, and having exhibited what the Gnostic is in his life, proceed to show the philosophers that he is by no means impious, as they suppose, but that he alone is truly pious, by a compendious exhibition of the Gnostic's form of religion, as far as it is possible, without danger, to commit it to writing in a book of reference.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 1:4
verses.text: For the Lord enjoined "to labour for the meat which endureth to eternity".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 1:5
verses.text: And the prophet says, "Blessed is he that soweth into all waters, whose ox and ass tread," that is, the people, from the Law and from the Gentiles, gathered into one faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 1:6
verses.text: "Now the weak eateth herbs," according to the noble apostle.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 1:7
verses.text: The Instructor, divided by us into three books, has already exhibited the training and nurture up from the state of childhood, that is, the course of life which from elementary instruction grows by faith; and in the case of those enrolled in the number of men, prepares beforehand the soul, endued with virtue, for the reception of gnostic knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 1:8
verses.text: The Greeks, then, clearly learning, from what shall be said by us in these pages, that in profanely persecuting the God-loving man, they themselves act impiously; then, as the notes advance, in accordance with the style of the Miscellanies, we must solve the difficulties raised both by Greeks and Barbarians with respect to the coming of the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 1:9
verses.text: In a meadow the flowers blooming variously, and in a park the plantations of fruit trees, are not separated according to their species from those of other kinds.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 1:10
verses.text: If some, culling varieties, have composed learned collections, Meadows, and Helicons, and Honeycombs, and Robes; then, with the things which come to recollection by haphazard, and are expurgated neither in order nor expression, but purposely scattered, the form of the Miscellanies is promiscuously variegated like a meadow.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 1:11
verses.text: And such being the case, my notes shall serve as kindling sparks; and in the case of him, who is fit for knowledge, if he chance to fall in with them, research made with exertion will turn out to his benefit and advantage.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 1:12
verses.text: For it is right that labour should precede not only food but also, much more knowledge, in the case of those that are advancing to the eternal and blessed salvation by the "strait and narrow way," which is truly the Lord's.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 1:13
verses.text: Our knowledge, and our spiritual garden, is the Saviour Himself; into whom we are planted, being transferred and transplanted, from our old life, into the good land.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 1:14
verses.text: And transplanting contributes to fruitfulness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 1:15
verses.text: The Lord, then, into whom we have been transplanted, is the Light and the true Knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 1:16
verses.text: Now knowledge is otherwise spoken of in a twofold sense: that, commonly so called, which appears in all men (similarly also comprehension and apprehension), universally, in the knowledge of individual objects; in which not only the rational powers, but equally the irrational, share, which I would never term knowledge, inasmuch as the apprehension of things through the senses comes naturally.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 1:17
verses.text: But that which par excellence is termed knowledge, bears the impress of judgment and reason, in the exercise of which there will be rational cognitions alone, applying purely to objects of thought, and resulting from the bare energy of the soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 1:18
verses.text: "He is a good man," says David, "who pities" (those ruined through error), "and lends" (from the communication of the word of truth) not at haphazard, for "he will dispense his words in judgment:" with profound calculation, "he hath dispersed, he hath given to the poor".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:1
verses.text: Chapter 2—The Subject of Plagiarisms Resumed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:2
verses.text: The Greeks Plagiarized from One Another.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:3
verses.text: Before handling the point proposed, we must, by way of preface, add to the close of the fifth book what is wanting.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:4
verses.text: For since we have shown that the symbolical style was ancient, and was employed not only by our prophets, but also by the majority of the ancient Greeks, and by not a few of the rest of the Gentile Barbarians, it was requisite to proceed to the mysteries of the initiated.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:5
verses.text: I postpone the elucidation of these till we advance to the confutation of what is said by the Greeks on first principles; for we shall show that the mysteries belong to the same branch of speculation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:6
verses.text: And having proved that the declaration of Hellenic thought is illuminated all round by the truth, bestowed on us in the Scriptures, taking it according to the sense, we have proved, not to say what is invidious, that the theft of the truth passed to them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:7
verses.text: Come, and let us adduce the Greeks as witnesses against themselves to the theft.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:8
verses.text: For, inasmuch as they pilfer from one another, they establish the fact that they are thieves; and although against their will, they are detected, clandestinely appropriating to those of their own race the truth which belongs to us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:9
verses.text: For if they do not keep their hands from each other, they will hardly do it from our authors.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:10
verses.text: I shall say nothing of philosophic dogmas, since the very persons who are the authors of the divisions into sects, confess in writing, so as not to be convicted of ingratitude, that they have received from Socrates the most important of their dogmas.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:11
verses.text: But after availing myself of a few testimonies of men most talked of, and of repute among the Greeks, and exposing their plagiarizing style, and selecting them from various periods, I shall turn to what follows.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:12
verses.text: Orpheus, then, having composed the line:—  "Since nothing else is more shameless and wretched than woman,"  Homer plainly says:—  "Since nothing else is more dreadful and shameless than a woman".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:13
verses.text: And Musaeus having written:—  "Since art is greatly superior to strength,"—  Homer says:—  "By art rather than strength is the woodcutter greatly superior".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:14
verses.text: Again, Musaeus having composed the lines:—  "And as the fruitful field produceth leaves, And on the ash trees some fade, others grow, So whirls the race of man its leaf,"—  Homer transcribes:—  "Some of the leaves the wind strews on the ground.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:15
verses.text: The budding wood bears some; in time of spring, They come.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:16
verses.text: So springs one race of men, and one departs".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:17
verses.text: Again, Homer having said:—  "It is unholy to exult over dead men,"  Archilochus and Cratinus write, the former:—  "It is not noble at dead men to sneer;"  and Cratinus in the Lacones:—  "For men 'tis dreadful to exult Much o'er the stalwart dead".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:18
verses.text: Again, Archilochus, transferring that Homeric line:—  "I erred, nor say I nay: instead of many"—  writes thus:—  "I erred, and this mischief hath somehow seized another".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:19
verses.text: As certainly also that line:—  "Even-handed war the slayer slays".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:20
verses.text: He also, altering, has given forth thus:—  "I will do it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:21
verses.text: For Mars to men in truth is evenhanded".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:22
verses.text: Also, translating the following:—  "The issues of victory among men depend on the gods,"  he openly encourages youth, in the following iambic:—  "Victory's issues on the gods depend".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:23
verses.text: Again, Homer having said:—  "With feet unwashed sleeping on the ground,"  Euripides writes in Erechtheus:—  "Upon the plain spread with no couch they sleep, Nor in the streams of water lave their feet".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:24
verses.text: Archilochus having likewise said:—  "But one with this and one with that His heart delights,"—  in correspondence with the Homeric line:—  "For one in these deeds, one in those delights,"—  Euripides says in oeneus:—  "But one in these ways, one in those, has more delight".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:25
verses.text: And I have heard aeschylus saying:—  "He who is happy ought to stay at home; There should he also stay, who speeds not well".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:26
verses.text: And Euripides, too, shouting the like on the stage:—  "Happy the man who, prosperous, stays at home".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:27
verses.text: Menander, too, on comedy, saying:—  "He ought at home to stay, and free remain, Or be no longer rightly happy".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:28
verses.text: Again, Theognis having said:—  "The exile has no comrade dear and true,"—  Euripides has written:—  "Far from the poor flies every friend".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:29
verses.text: And Epicharmus, saying:—  "Daughter, woe worth the day! Thee who art old I marry to a youth;"  and adding:—  "For the young husband takes some other girl, And for another husband longs the wife,"—  Euripides writes:—  "'Tis bad to yoke an old wife to a youth; For he desires to share another's bed, And she, by him deserted, mischief plots".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:30
verses.text: Euripides having, besides, said in the Medea:—  "For no good do a bad man's gifts,"—  Sophocles in Ajax Flagellifer utters this iambic:—  "For foes' gifts are no gifts, nor any boon".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:31
verses.text: Solon having written:—  "For surfeit insolence begets, When store of wealth attends".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:32
verses.text: Theognis writes in the same way:—  "For surfeit insolence begets, When store of wealth attends the bad".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:33
verses.text: Whence also Thucydides, in the Histories, says: "Many men, to whom in a great degree, and in a short time, unlooked-for prosperity comes, are wont to turn to insolence".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:34
verses.text: And Philistus likewise imitates the same sentiment, expressing himself thus: "And the many things which turn out prosperously to men, in accordance with reason, have an incredibly dangerous tendency to misfortune.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:35
verses.text: For those who meet with unlooked success beyond their expectations, are for the most part wont to turn to insolence".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:36
verses.text: Again, Euripides having written:—  "For children sprung of parents who have led A hard and toilsome life, superior are;"  Critias writes: "For I begin with a man's origin: how far the best and strongest in body will he be, if his father exercises himself, and eats in a hardy way, and subjects his body to toilsome labour; and if the mother of the future child be strong in body, and give herself exercise".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:37
verses.text: Again, Homer having said of the Hephaestus-made shield:—  "Upon it earth and heaven and sea he made, And Ocean's rivers' mighty strength portrayed,"  Pherecydes of Syros says:—"Zas makes a cloak large and beautiful, and works on it earth and Ogenus, and the palace of Ogenus".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:38
verses.text: And Homer having said:—  "Shame, which greatly hurts a man or helps,"—  Euripides writes in Erechtheus:—  "Of shame I find it hard to judge; 'Tis needed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:39
verses.text: 'Tis at times a great mischief".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:40
verses.text: Take, by way of parallel, such plagiarisms as the following, from those who flourished together, and were rivals of each other.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:41
verses.text: From the Orestes of Euripides:—  "Dear charm of sleep, aid in disease".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:42
verses.text: From the Eriphyle of Sophocles:—  "Hie thee to sleep, healer of that disease".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:43
verses.text: And from the Antigone of Sophocles:—  "Bastardy is opprobrious in name; but the nature is equal;"  And from the Aleuades of Sophocles:—  "Each good thing has its nature equal".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:44
verses.text: Again, in the Ctimenus of Euripides:—  "For him who toils, God helps;"  And in the Minos of Sophocles;  "To those who act not, fortune is no ally;"  And from the Alexander of Euripides:—  "But time will show; and learning, by that test, I shall know whether thou art good or bad;"  And from the Hipponos of Sophocles:—  "Besides, conceal thou nought; since Time, That sees all, hears all, all things will unfold".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:45
verses.text: But let us similarly run over the following; for Eumelus having composed the line,  "Of Memory and Olympian Zeus the daughters nine,"  Solon thus begins the elegy:—  "Of Memory and Olympian Zeus the children bright".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:46
verses.text: Again, Euripides, paraphrasing the Homeric line:—  "What, whence art thou? Thy city and thy parents, where?"  employs the following iambics in aegeus:—  "What country shall we say that thou hast left To roam in exile, what thy land—the bound Of thine own native soil? Who thee begat? And of what father dost thou call thyself the son?"  And what? Theognis having said:—  "Wine largely drunk is bad; but if one use It with discretion, 'tis not bad, but good,"—  does not Panyasis write?  "Above the gods' best gift to men ranks wine, In measure drunk; but in excess the worst".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:47
verses.text: Hesiod, too, saying:—  "But for the fire to thee I'll give a plague, For all men to delight themselves withal,"—  Euripides writes:—  "And for the fire Another fire greater and unconquerable, Sprung up in the shape of women"  And in addition, Homer, saying:—  "There is no satiating the greedy paunch, Baneful, which many plagues has caused to men".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:48
verses.text: Euripides says:—  "Dire need and baneful paunch me overcome; From which all evils come".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:49
verses.text: Besides, Callias the comic poet having written:—  "With madmen, all men must be mad, they say,"—  Menander, in the Poloumenoi, expresses himself similarly, saying:—  "The presence of wisdom is not always suitable: One sometimes must with others play the fool".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:50
verses.text: And Antimachus of Teos having said:—  "From gifts, to mortals many ills arise,"—  Augias composed the line:—  "For gifts men's mind and acts deceive".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:51
verses.text: And Hesiod having said:—  "Than a good wife, no man a better thing Ere gained; than a bad wife, a worse,"—  Simonides said:—  "A better prize than a good wife no man Ere gained, than a bad one nought worse".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:52
verses.text: Again, Epicharmas having said:—  "As destined long to live, and yet not long, Think of thyself".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:53
verses.text: —  Euripides writes:—  "Why? seeing the wealth we have uncertain is, Why don't we live as free from care, as pleasant As we may?"  Similarly also, the comic poet Diphilus having said:—  "The life of men is prone to change,"—  Posidippus says:—  "No man of mortal mould his life has passed From suffering free.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:54
verses.text: Nor to the end again Has continued prosperous".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:55
verses.text: Similarly speaks to thee Plato, writing of man as a creature subject to change.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:56
verses.text: Again, Euripides having said:—  "Oh life to mortal men of trouble full, How slippery in everything art thou! Now grow'st thou, and thou now decay'st away.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:57
verses.text: And there is set no limit, no, not one, For mortals of their course to make an end, Except when Death's remorseless final end Comes, sent from Zeus,"—  Diphilus writes:—  "There is no life which has not its own ills, Pains, cares, thefts, and anxieties, disease; And Death, as a physician, coming, gives Rest to their victims in his quiet sleep".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:58
verses.text: Furthermore, Euripides having said:—  "Many are fortune's shapes, And many things contrary to expectation the gods perform,"—  The tragic poet Theodectes similarly writes:—  "The instability of mortals' fates".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:59
verses.text: And Bacchylides having said:—  "To few alone of mortals is it given To reach hoary age, being prosperous all the while, And not meet with calamities,"—  Moschion, the comic poet, writes:—  "But he of all men is most blest, Who leads throughout an equal life".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:60
verses.text: And you will find that, Theognis having said:—  "For no advantage to a man grown old A young wife is, who will not, as a ship The helm, obey,"—  Aristophanes, the comic poet, writes:—  "An old man to a young wife suits but ill".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:61
verses.text: For Anacreon, having written:—  "Luxurious love I sing, With flowery garlands graced, He is of gods the king, He mortal men subdues,—  Euripides writes:—  "For love not only men attacks, And women; but disturbs The souls of gods above, and to the sea Descends".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:62
verses.text: But not to protract the discourse further, in our anxiety to show the propensity of the Greeks to plagiarism in expressions and dogmas, allow us to adduce the express testimony of Hippias, the sophist of Elea, who discourses on the point in hand, and speaks thus: "Of these things some perchance are said by Orpheus, some briefly by Musaeus; some in one place, others in other places; some by Hesiod, some by Homer, some by the rest of the poets; and some in prose compositions, some by Greeks, some by Barbarians.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:63
verses.text: And I from all these, placing together the things of most importance and of kindred character, will make the present discourse new and varied".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:64
verses.text: And in order that we may see that philosophy and history, and even rhetoric, are not free of a like reproach, it is right to adduce a few instances from them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:65
verses.text: For Alcmaeon of Crotona having said, "It is easier to guard against a man who is an enemy than a friend," Sophocles wrote in the Antigone:—  "For what sore more grievous than a bad friend?"  And Xenophon said: "No man can injure enemies in any way other than by appearing to be a friend".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:66
verses.text: And Euripides having said in Telephus:—  "Shall we Greeks be slaves to Barbarians?"—  Thrasymachus, in the oration for the Larissaeans, says: "Shall we be slaves to Archelaus—Greeks to a Barbarian?"  And Orpheus having said:—  "Water is the change for soul, and death for water; From water is earth, and what comes from earth is again water, And from that, soul, which changes the whole ether;"  and Heraclitus, putting together the expressions from these lines, writes thus:—  "It is death for souls to become water, and death for water to become earth; and from earth comes water, and from water soul".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:67
verses.text: And Athamas the Pythagorean having said, "Thus was produced the beginning of the universe; and there are four roots—fire, water, air, earth: for from these is the origination of what is produced,"—Empedocles of Agrigentum wrote:—  "The four roots of all things first do thou hear— Fire, water, earth, and ether's boundless height: For of these all that was, is, shall be, comes".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:68
verses.text: And Plato having said, "Wherefore also the gods, knowing men, release sooner from life those they value most," Menander wrote:—  "Whom the gods love, dies young".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:69
verses.text: And Euripides having written in the oenomaus:—  "We judge of things obscure from what we see;"  and in the Phoenix:—  "By signs the obscure is fairly grasped,"—  Hyperides says, "But we must investigate things unseen by learning from signs and probabilities".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:70
verses.text: And Isocrates having said, "We must conjecture the future by the past," Andocides does not shrink from saying, "For we must make use of what has happened previously as signs in reference to what is to be".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:71
verses.text: Besides, Theognis having said:—  "The evil of counterfeit silver and gold is not intolerable, O Cyrnus, and to a wise man is not difficult of detection; But if the mind of a friend is hidden in his breast, If he is false, and has a treacherous heart within, This is the basest thing for mortals, caused by God, And of all things the hardest to detect,"—  Euripides writes:—  "Oh Zeus, why hast thou given to men clear tests Of spurious gold, while on the body grows No mark sufficing to discover clear The wicked man?"  Hyperides himself also says, "There is no feature of the mind impressed on the countenance of men".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:72
verses.text: Again, Stasinus having composed the line:—  "Fool, who, having slain the father, leaves the children,"—  Xenophon says, "For I seem to myself to have acted in like manner, as if one who killed the father should spare his children".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:73
verses.text: And Sophocles having written in the Antigone:—  "Mother and father being in Hades now, No brother ever can to me spring forth,"—  Herodotus says, "Mother and father being no more, I shall not have another brother".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:74
verses.text: In addition to these, Theopompus having written:—  "Twice children are old men in very truth;"  And before him Sophocles in Peleus:—  "Peleus, the son of aeacus, I, sole housekeeper, Guide, old as he is now, and train again, For the aged man is once again a child,"—  Antipho the orator says, "For the nursing of the old is like the nursing of children".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:75
verses.text: Also the  philosopher Plato says, "The old man then, as seems, will be twice a child".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:76
verses.text: Further, Thucydides having said, "We alone bore the brunt at Marathon,"—Demosthenes said, "By those who bore the brunt at Marathon".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:77
verses.text: Nor will I omit the following.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:78
verses.text: Cratinus having said in the Pytine:—  "The preparation perchance you know,"  Andocides the orator says, "The preparation, gentlemen of the jury, and the eagerness of our enemies, almost all of you know".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:79
verses.text: Similarly also Nicias, in the speech on the deposit, against Lysias, says, "The preparation and the eagerness of the adversaries, ye see, O gentlemen of the jury".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:80
verses.text: After him aeschines says, "You see the preparation, O men of Athens, and the line of battle".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:81
verses.text: Again, Demosthenes having said, "What zeal and what canvassing, O men of Athens, have been employed in this contest, I think almost all of you are aware;" and Philinus similarly, "What zeal, what forming of the line of battle, gentlemen of the jury, have taken place in this contest, I think not one of you is ignorant".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:82
verses.text: Isocrates, again, having said, "As if she were related to his wealth, not him," Lysias says in the Orphics, "And he was plainly related not to the persons, but to the money".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:83
verses.text: Since Homer also having written:—  "O friend, if in this war, by taking flight, We should from age and death exemption win, I would not fight among the first myself, Nor would I send thee to the glorious fray; But now—for myriad fates of death attend In any case, which man may not escape Or shun—come on.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:84
verses.text: To some one we shall bring Renown, or some one shall to us,"—  Theopompus writes, "For if, by avoiding the present danger, we were to pass the rest of our time in security, to show love of life would not be wonderful.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:85
verses.text: But now, so many fatalities are incident to life, that death in battle seems preferable".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:86
verses.text: And what? Child the sophist having uttered the apophthegm, "Become surety, and mischief is at hand," did not Epicharmus utter the same sentiment in other terms, when he said, "Suretyship is the daughter of mischief, and loss that of suretyship?" Further, Hippocrates the physician having written, "You must look to time, and locality, and age, and disease," Euripides says in Hexameters:—  "Those who the healing art would practice well, Must study people's modes of life, and note The soil, and the diseases so consider".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:87
verses.text: Homer again, having written:—  "I say no mortal man can doom escape,"—  Archinus says, "All men are bound to die either sooner or later;" and Demosthenes, "To all men death is the end of life, though one should keep himself shut up in a coop".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:88
verses.text: And Herodotus, again, having said, in his discourse about Glaucus the Spartan, that the Pythian said, "In the case of the Deity, to say and to do are equivalent," Aristophanes said:—  "For to think and to do are equivalent".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:89
verses.text: And before him, Parmenides of Elea said:—  "For thinking and being are the same".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:90
verses.text: And Plato having said, "And we shall show, not absurdly perhaps, that the beginning of love is sight; and hope diminishes the passion, memory nourishes it, and intercourse preserves it;" does not Philemon the comic poet write:—  "First all see, then admire; Then gaze, then come to hope; And thus arises love?"  Further, Demosthenes having said, "For to all of us death is a debt," and so forth, Phanocles writes in Loves, or The Beautiful:—  "But from the Fates' unbroken thread escape Is none for those that feed on earth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:91
verses.text: You will also find that Plato having said, "For the first sprout of each plant, having got a fair start, according to the virtue of its own nature, is most powerful in inducing the appropriate end;" the historian writes, "Further, it is not natural for one of the wild plants to become cultivated, after they have passed the earlier period of growth;" and the following of Empedocles:—  "For I already have been boy and girl, And bush, and bird, and mute fish in the sea,"—  Euripides transcribes in Chrysippus:—  "But nothing dies Of things that are; but being dissolved, One from the other, Shows another form".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:92
verses.text: And Plato having said, in the Republic, that women were common, Euripides writes in the Protesilaus:—  "For common, then, is woman's bed".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:93
verses.text: Further, Euripides having written:—  "For to the temperate enough sufficient is"—  Epicurus expressly says, "Sufficiency is the greatest riches of all".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:94
verses.text: Again, Aristophanes having written:—  "Life thou securely shalt enjoy, being just And free from turmoil, and from fear live well,"—  Epicurus says, "The greatest fruit of righteousness is tranquillity".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:95
verses.text: Let these species, then, of Greek plagiarism of sentiments, being such, stand as sufficient for a clear specimen to him who is capable of perceiving.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:96
verses.text: And not only have they been detected pirating and paraphrasing thoughts and expressions, as will be shown; but they will also be convicted of the possession of what is entirely stolen.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:97
verses.text: For stealing entirely what is the production of others, they have published it as their own; as Eugamon of Cyrene did the entire book on the Thesprotians from Musaeus, and Pisander of Camirus the Heraclea of Pisinus of Lindus, and Panyasis of Halicarnassus, the capture of oechalia from Cleophilus of Samos.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:98
verses.text: You will also find that Homer, the great poet, took from Orpheus, from the Disappearance of Dionysus, those words and what follows verbatim:—  "As a man trains a luxuriant shoot of olive".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:99
verses.text: And in the Theogony, it is said by Orpheus of Kronos:—  "He lay, his thick neck bent aside; and him All-conquering Sleep had seized".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:100
verses.text: These Homer transferrred to the Cyclops.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:101
verses.text: And Hesiod writes of Melampous:—  "Gladly to hear, what the immortals have assigned To men, the brave from cowards clearly marks;"  and so forth, taking it word for word from the poet Musaeus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:102
verses.text: And Aristophanes the comic poet has, in the first of the Thesmophoriazusae, transferred the words from the Empiprameni of Cratinus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:103
verses.text: And Plato the comic poet, and Aristophanes in Daedalus, steal from one another.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:104
verses.text: Cocalus, composed by Araros, the son of Aristophanes, was by the comic poet Philemon altered, and made into the comedy called Hypobolimoens.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:105
verses.text: Eumelus and Acusilaus the historiographers changed the contents of Hesiod into prose, and published them as their own.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:106
verses.text: Gorgias of Leontium and Eudemus of Naxus, the historians, stole from Melesagoras.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:107
verses.text: And, besides, there is Bion of Proconnesus, who epitomized and transcribed the writings of the ancient Cadmus, and Archilochus, and Aristotle, and Leandrus, and Hellanicus, and Hecataeus, and Androtion, and Philochorus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:108
verses.text: Dieuchidas of Megara transferred the beginning of his treatise from the Deucalion of Hellanicus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:109
verses.text: I pass over in silence Heraclitus of Ephesus, who took a very great deal from Orpheus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:110
verses.text: From Pythagoras Plato derived the immortality of the soul; and he from the Egyptians.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:111
verses.text: And many of the Platonists composed books, in which they show that the Stoics, as we said in the beginning, and Aristotle, took the most and principal of their dogmas from Plato.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:112
verses.text: Epicurus also pilfered his leading dogmas from Democritus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:113
verses.text: Let these things then be so.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 2:114
verses.text: For life would fail me, were I to undertake to go over the subject in detail, to expose the selfish plagiarism of the Greeks, and how they claim the discovery of the best of their doctrines, which they have received from us.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:1
verses.text: Chapter 3—Plagiarism by the Greeks of the Miracles Related in the Sacred Books of the Hebrews.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:2
verses.text: And now they are convicted not only of borrowing doctrines from the Barbarians, but also of relating as prodigies of Hellenic mythology the marvels found in our records, wrought through divine power from above, by those who led holy lives, while devoting attention to us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:3
verses.text: And we shall ask at them whether those things which they relate are true or false.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:4
verses.text: But they will not say that they are false; for they will not with their will condemn themselves of the very great silliness of composing falsehoods, but of necessity admit them to be true.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:5
verses.text: And how will the prodigies enacted by Moses and the other prophets any longer appear to them incredible? For the Almighty God, in His care for all men, turns some to salvation by commands, some by threats, some by miraculous signs, some by gentle promises.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:6
verses.text: Well, the Greeks, when once a drought had wasted Greece for a protracted period, and a dearth of the fruits of the earth ensued, it is said, those that survived of them, having, because of the famine, come as suppliants to Delphi, asked the Pythian priestess how they should be released from the calamity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:7
verses.text: She announced that the only help in their distress was, that they should avail themselves of the prayers of aeacus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:8
verses.text: Prevailed on by them, aeacus, ascending the Hellenic hill, and stretching out pure hands to heaven, and invoking the common God, besought him to pity wasted Greece.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:9
verses.text: And as he prayed, thunder sounded, out of the usual course of things, and the whole surrounding atmosphere was covered with clouds.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:10
verses.text: And impetuous and continued rains, bursting down, filled the whole region.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:11
verses.text: The result was a copious and rich fertility wrought by the husbandry of the prayers of aeacus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:12
verses.text: "And Samuel called on the Lord," it is said, "and the Lord gave forth His voice, and rain in the day of harvest".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:13
verses.text: Do you see that "He who sendeth His rain on the just and on the  unjust" by the subject powers is the one God? And the whole of our Scripture is full of instances of God, in reference to the prayers of the just, hearing and performing each one of their petitions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:14
verses.text: Again, the Greeks relate, that in the case of a failure once of the Etesian winds, Aristaeus once sacrificed in Ceus to Isthmian Zeus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:15
verses.text: For there was great devastation, everything being burnt up with the heat in consequence of the winds which had been wont to refresh the productions of the earth, not blowing, and he easily called them back.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:16
verses.text: And at Delphi, on the expedition of Xerxes against Greece, the Pythian priestess having made answer:—  "O Delphians, pray the winds, and it will be better,"—  they having erected an altar and performed sacrifice to the winds, had them as their helpers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:17
verses.text: For, blowing violently around Cape Sepias, they shivered the whole preparations of the Persian expedition.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:18
verses.text: Empedocles of Agrigentum was called "Checker of Winds".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:19
verses.text: Accordingly it is said, that when, on a time, a wind blew from the mountain of Agrigentum, heavy and pestiferous for the inhabitants, and the cause also of barrenness to their wives, he made the wind to cease.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:20
verses.text: Wherefore he himself writes in the lines:—  "Thou shalt the might of the unwearied winds make still, Which rushing to the earth spoil mortals' crops, And at thy will bring back the avenging blasts".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:21
verses.text: And they say that he was followed by some that used divinations, and some that had been long vexed by sore diseases.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:22
verses.text: They plainly, then, believed in the performance of cures, and signs and wonders, from our Scriptures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:23
verses.text: For if certain powers move the winds and dispense showers, let them hear the psalmist: "How amiable are thy tabernacles, O Lord of hosts!" This is the Lord of powers, and principalities, and authorities, of whom Moses speaks; so that we may be with Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:24
verses.text: "And ye shall circumcise your hard heart, and shall not harden your neck any more.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:25
verses.text: For He is Lord of lords and God of gods, the great God and strong," unit so forth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:26
verses.text: And Isaiah says, "Lift your eyes to the height, and see who hath produced all these things".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:27
verses.text: And some say that plagues, and hail-storms, and tempests, and the like, are wont to take place, not alone in consequence of material disturbance, but also through anger of demons and bad angels.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:28
verses.text: For instance, they say that the Magi at Cleone, watching the phenomena of the skies, when the clouds are about to discharge hail, avert the threatening of wrath by incantations and sacrifices.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:29
verses.text: And if at any time there is the want of an animal, they are satisfied with bleeding their own finger for a sacrifice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:30
verses.text: The prophetess Diotima, by the Athenians offering sacrifice previous to the pestilence, effected a delay of the plague for ten years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:31
verses.text: The sacrifices, too, of Epimenides of Crete, put off the Persian war for an equal period.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:32
verses.text: And it is considered to be all the same whether we call these spirits gods or angels.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:33
verses.text: And those skilled in the matter of consecrating statues, in many of the temples have erected tombs of the dead, calling the souls of these Daemons, and teaching them to be worshipped by men; as having, in consequence of the purity of their life, by the divine foreknowledge, received the power of wandering about the space around the earth in order to minister to men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:34
verses.text: For they knew that some souls were by nature kept in the body.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:35
verses.text: But of these, as the work proceeds, in the treatise on the angels, we shall discourse.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:36
verses.text: Democritus, who predicted many things from observation of celestial phenomena, was called "Wisdom" (Σοφία).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:37
verses.text: On his meeting a cordial reception from his brother Damasus, he predicted that there would be much rain, judging from certain stars.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:38
verses.text: Some, accordingly, convinced by him, gathered their crops; for being in summer-time, they were still on the threshing-floor.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:39
verses.text: But others lost all, unexpected and heavy showers having burst down.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:40
verses.text: How then shall the Greeks any longer disbelieve the divine appearance on Mount Sinai, when the fire burned, consuming none of the things that grew on the mount; and the sound of trumpets issued forth, breathed without instruments? For that which is called the descent on the mount of God is the advent of divine power, pervading the whole world, and proclaiming "the light that is inaccessible".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:41
verses.text: For such is the allegory, according to the Scripture.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:42
verses.text: But the fire was seen, as Aristobulus says, while the whole multitude, amounting to not less than a million, besides those under age, were congregated around the mountain, the circuit of the mount not being less than five days' journey.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:43
verses.text: Over the whole place of the vision the burning fire was seen by them all encamped as it were around; so that the descent was not local.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:44
verses.text: For God is everywhere.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:45
verses.text: Now the compilers of narratives say that in the island of Britain there is a cave situated under a mountain, and a chasm on its summit;  and that, accordingly, when the wind falls into the cave, and rushes into the bosom of the cleft, a sound is heard like cymbals clashing musically.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:46
verses.text: And often in the woods, when the leaves are moved by a sudden gust of wind, a sound is emitted like the song of birds.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:47
verses.text: Those also who composed the Persics relate that in the uplands, in the country of the Magi, three mountains are situated on an extended plain, and that those who travel through the locality, on coming to the first mountain, hear a confused sound as of several myriads shouting, as if in battle array; and on reaching the middle one, they hear a clamour louder and more distinct; and at the end hear people singing a paean, as if victorious.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:48
verses.text: And the cause, in my opinion, of the whole sound, is the smoothness and cavernous character of the localities; and the air, entering in, being sent back and going to the same point, sounds with considerable force.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:49
verses.text: Let these things be so.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:50
verses.text: But it is possible for God Almighty, even without a medium, to produce a voice and vision through the ear, showing that His greatness has a natural order beyond what is customary, in order to the conversion of the hitherto unbelieving soul, and the reception of the commandment given.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:51
verses.text: But there being a cloud and a lofty mountain, how is it not possible to hear a different sound, the wind moving by the active cause? Wherefore also the prophet says, "Ye heard the voice of words, and saw no similitude".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 3:52
verses.text: You see how the Lord's voice, the Word, without shape, the power of the Word, the luminous word of the Lord, the truth from heaven, from above, coming to the assembly of the Church, wrought by the luminous immediate ministry.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4:1
verses.text: Chapter 4—The Greeks Drew Many of Their Philosophical Tenets from the Egyptian and Indian Gymnosophists.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4:2
verses.text: We shall find another testimony in confirmation, in the fact that the best of the philosophers, having appropriated their most excellent dogmas from us, boast, as it were, of certain of the tenets which pertain to each sect being culled from other Barbarians, chiefly from the Egyptians—both other tenets, and that especially of the transmigration of the soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4:3
verses.text: For the Egyptians pursue a philosophy of their own.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4:4
verses.text: This is principally shown by their sacred ceremonial.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4:5
verses.text: For first advances the Singer, bearing some one of the symbols of music.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4:6
verses.text: For they say that he must learn two of the books of Hermes, the one of which contains the hymns of the gods, the second the regulations for the king's life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4:7
verses.text: And after the Singer advances the Astrologer, with a horologe in his hand, and a palm, the symbols of astrology.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4:8
verses.text: He must have the astrological books of Hermes, which are four in number, always in his mouth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4:9
verses.text: Of these, one is about the order of the fixed stars that are visible, and another about the conjunctions and luminous appearances of the sun and moon; and the rest respecting their risings.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4:10
verses.text: Next in order advances the sacred Scribe, with wings on his head, and in his hand a book and rule, in which were writing ink and the reed, with which they write.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4:11
verses.text: And he must be acquainted with what are called hieroglyphics, and know about cosmography and geography, the position of the sun and moon, and about the five planets; also the description of Egypt, and the chart of the Nile; and the description of the equipment of the priests and of the places consecrated to them, and about the measures and the things in use in the sacred rites.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4:12
verses.text: Then the Stole-keeper follows those previously mentioned, with the cubit of justice and the cup for libations.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4:13
verses.text: He is acquainted with all points called Paedeutic (relating to training) and Moschophatic (sacrificial).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4:14
verses.text: There are also ten books which relate to the honour paid by them to their gods, and containing the Egyptian worship; as that relating to sacrifices, first-fruits, hymns, prayers, processions, festivals, and the like.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4:15
verses.text: And behind all walks the Prophet, with the water-vase carried openly in his arms; who is followed by those who carry the issue of loaves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4:16
verses.text: He, as being the governor of the temple, learns the ten books called "Hieratic;" and they contain all about the laws, and the gods, and the whole of the training of the priests.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4:17
verses.text: For the Prophet is, among the Egyptians, also over the distribution of the revenues.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4:18
verses.text: There are then forty-two books of Hermes indispensably necessary; of which the six-and-thirty containing the whole philosophy of the Egyptians are learned by the forementioned personages; and the other six, which are medical, by the Pastophoroi (image-bearers),—treating of the structure of the body, and of diseases, and instruments, and medicines, and about the eyes, and the last about women.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4:19
verses.text: Such are the customs of the Egyptians, to speak briefly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4:20
verses.text: The philosophy of the Indians, too, has been celebrated.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4:21
verses.text: Alexander of Macedon, having taken ten of the Indian Gymnosophists, that seemed the best and most sententious, proposed to them problems, threatening to put to death him that did not answer to the purpose; ordering one, who was the eldest of them, to decide.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4:22
verses.text: The first, then, being asked whether he thought that the living were more in number than the dead, said, The living; for that the  dead were not.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4:23
verses.text: The second, on being asked whether the sea or the land maintained larger beasts, said, The land; for the sea was part of it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4:24
verses.text: And the third being asked which was the most cunning of animals? The one, which has not hitherto been known, man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4:25
verses.text: And the fourth being interrogated, For what reason they had made Sabba, who was their prince, revolt, answered, Because they wished him to live well rather than die ill.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4:26
verses.text: And the fifth being asked, Whether he thought that day or night was first, said, One day.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4:27
verses.text: For puzzling questions must have puzzling answers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4:28
verses.text: And the sixth being posed with the query, How shall one be loved most? By being most powerful; in order that he may not be timid.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4:29
verses.text: And the seventh being asked, How any one of men could become God? said, If he do what it is impossible for man to do.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4:30
verses.text: And the eighth being asked, Which is the stronger, life or death? said, Life, which bears such ills.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4:31
verses.text: And the ninth being interrogated, Up to what point it is good for a man to live? said, Till he does not think that to die is better than to live.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4:32
verses.text: And on Alexander ordering the tenth to say something, for he was judge, he said, "One spake worse than another".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 4:33
verses.text: And on Alexander saying, Shall you not, then, die first, having given such a judgment? he said, And how, O king, wilt thou prove true, after saying that thou wouldest kill first the first man that answered very badly?  And that the Greeks are called pilferers of all manner of writing, is, as I think, sufficiently demonstrated by abundant proofs.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 5

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 5:1
verses.text: Chapter 5—The Greeks Had Some Knowledge of the True God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 5:2
verses.text: And that the men of highest repute among the Greeks knew God, not by positive knowledge, but by indirect expression, Peter says in the Preaching: "Know then that there is one God, who made the beginning of all things, and holds the power of the end; and is the Invisible, who sees all things; incapable of being contained, who contains all things; needing nothing, whom all things need, and by whom they are; incomprehensible, everlasting, unmade, who made all things by the 'Word of His power,' that is, according to the gnostic scripture, His Son".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 5:3
verses.text: Then he adds: "Worship this God not as the Greeks,"—signifying plainly, that the excellent among the Greeks worshipped the same God as we, but that they had not learned by perfect knowledge that which was delivered by the Son.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 5:4
verses.text: "Do not then worship," he did not say, the God whom the Greeks worship, but "as the Greeks,"—changing the manner of the worship of God, not announcing another God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 5:5
verses.text: What, then, the expression "not as the Greeks" means, Peter himself shall explain, as he adds: "Since they are carried away by ignorance, and know not God" (as we do, according to the perfect knowledge); "but giving shape to the things of which He gave them the power for use—stocks and stones, brass and iron, gold and silver—matter;—and setting up the things which are slaves for use and possession, worship them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 5:6
verses.text: And what God hath given to them for food—the fowls of the air, and the fish of the sea, and the creeping things of the earth, and the wild beasts with the four-footed cattle of the field, weasels and mice, cats and dogs and apes, and their own proper food—they sacrifice as sacrifices to mortals; and offering dead things to the dead, as to gods, are unthankful to God, denying His existence by these things".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 5:7
verses.text: And that it is said, that we and the Greeks know the same God, though not in the same way, he will infer thus: "Neither worship as the Jews; for they, thinking that they only know God, do not know Him, adoring as they do angels and archangels, the month and the moon.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 5:8
verses.text: And if the moon be not visible, they do not hold the Sabbath, which is called the first; nor do they hold the new moon, nor the feast of unleavened bread, nor the feast, nor the great day".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 5:9
verses.text: Then he gives the finishing stroke to the question: "So that do ye also, learning holily and righteously what we deliver to you; keep them, worshipping God in a new way, by Christ".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 5:10
verses.text: For we find in the Scriptures, as the Lord says: "Behold, I make with you a new covenant, not as I made with your fathers in Mount Horeb".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 5:11
verses.text: He made a new covenant with us; for what belonged to the Greeks and Jews is old.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 5:12
verses.text: But we, who worship Him in a new way, in the third form, are Christians.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 5:13
verses.text: For clearly, as I think, he showed that the one and only God was known by the Greeks in a Gentile way, by the Jews Judaically, and in a new and spiritual way by us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 5:14
verses.text: And further, that the same God that furnished both the Covenants was the giver of Greek philosophy to the Greeks, by which the Almighty is glorified among the Greeks, he shows.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 5:15
verses.text: And it is clear from this.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 5:16
verses.text: Accordingly, then, from the  Hellenic training, and also from that of the law are gathered into the one race of the saved people those who accept faith: not that the three peoples are separated by time, so that one might suppose three natures, but trained in different Covenants of the one Lord, by the word of the one Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 5:17
verses.text: For that, as God wished to save the Jews by giving to them prophets, so also by raising up prophets of their own in their own tongue, as they were able to receive God's beneficence, He distinguished the most excellent of the Greeks from the common herd, in addition to "Peter's Preaching," the Apostle Paul will show, saying: "Take also the Hellenic books, read the Sibyl, how it is shown that God is one, and how the future is indicated.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 5:18
verses.text: And taking Hystaspes, read, and you will find much more luminously and distinctly the Son of God described, and how many kings shall draw up their forces against Christ, hating Him and those that bear His name, and His faithful ones, and His patience, and His coming".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 5:19
verses.text: Then in one word he asks us, "Whose is the world, and all that is in the world? Are they not God's?" Wherefore Peter says, that the Lord said to the apostles: "If any one of Israel then, wishes to repent, and by my name to believe in God, his sins shall be forgiven him, after twelve years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 5:20
verses.text: Go forth into the world, that no one may say, We have not heard".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:1
verses.text: Chapter 6—The Gospel Was Preached to Jews and Gentiles in Hades.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:2
verses.text: But as the proclamation of the Gospel has come now at the fit time, so also at the fit time were the Law and the Prophets given to the Barbarians, and Philosophy to the Greeks, to fit their ears for the Gospel.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:3
verses.text: "Therefore," says the Lord who delivered Israel, "in an acceptable time have I heard thee, and in a day of salvation have I helped thee.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:4
verses.text: And I have given thee for a Covenant to the nations; that thou mightest inhabit the earth, and receive the inheritance of the wilderness; saying to those that are in bonds, Come forth; and to those that are in darkness, Show yourselves".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:5
verses.text: For if the "prisoners" are the Jews, of whom the Lord said, "Come forth, ye that will, from your bonds,"—meaning the voluntary bound, and who have taken on them "the burdens grievous to be borne" by human injunction—it is plain that "those in darkness" are they who have the ruling faculty of the soul buried in idolatry.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:6
verses.text: For to those who were righteous according to the law, faith was wanting.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:7
verses.text: Wherefore also the Lord, in healing them, said, "Thy faith hath saved thee".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:8
verses.text: But to those that were righteous according to philosophy, not only faith in the Lord, but also the abandonment of idolatry, were necessary.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:9
verses.text: Straightway, on the revelation of the truth, they also repented of their previous conduct.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:10
verses.text: Wherefore the Lord preached the Gospel to those in Hades.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:11
verses.text: Accordingly the Scripture says, "Hades says to Destruction, We have not seen His form, but we have heard His voice".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:12
verses.text: It is not plainly the place, which, the words above say, heard the voice, but those who have been put in Hades, and have abandoned themselves to destruction, as persons who have thrown themselves voluntarily from a ship into the sea.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:13
verses.text: They, then, are those that hear the divine power and voice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:14
verses.text: For who in his senses can suppose the souls of the righteous and those of sinners in the same condemnation, charging Providence with injustice?  But how? Do not the Scriptures show that the Lord preached the Gospel to those that perished in the flood, or rather had been chained, and to those kept "in ward and guard"? And it has been shown also, in the second book of the Stromata, that the apostles, following the Lord, preached the Gospel to those in Hades.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:15
verses.text: For it was requisite, in my opinion, that as here, so also there, the best of the disciples should be imitators of the Master; so that He should bring to repentance those belonging to the Hebrews, and they the Gentiles; that is, those who had lived in righteousness according to the Law and Philosophy, who had ended life not perfectly, but sinfully.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:16
verses.text: For it was suitable to the divine administration, that those possessed of greater worth in righteousness, and whose life had been pre-eminent, on repenting of their transgressions, though found in another place, yet being confessedly of the number of the people of God Almighty, should be saved, each one according to his individual knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:17
verses.text: And, as I think, the Saviour also exerts His might because it is His work to save; which accordingly He also did by drawing to salvation those who became willing, by the preaching of the Gospel, to believe on Him, wherever they were.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:18
verses.text: If, then, the Lord descended to Hades for no other end but to preach the Gospel, as He did descend; it was either to preach the Gospel to all or to the Hebrews only.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:19
verses.text: If, accordingly, to all, then all who believe shall be saved, although they may be of the Gentiles, on making their profession there; since God's punishments  are saving and disciplinary, leading to conversion, and choosing rather the repentance them the death of a sinner; and especially since souls, although darkened by passions, when released from their bodies, are able to perceive more clearly, because of their being no longer obstructed by the paltry flesh.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:20
verses.text: If, then, He preached only to the Jews, who wanted the knowledge and faith of the Saviour, it is plain that, since God is no respecter of persons, the apostles also, as here, so there preached the Gospel to those of the heathen who were ready for conversion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:21
verses.text: And it is well said by the Shepherd, "They went down with them therefore into the water, and again ascended.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:22
verses.text: But these descended alive, and again ascended alive.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:23
verses.text: But those who had fallen asleep, descended dead, but ascended alive".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:24
verses.text: Further the Gospel says, "that many bodies of those that slept arose,"—plainly as having been translated to a better state.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:25
verses.text: There took place, then, a universal movement and translation through the economy of the Saviour.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:26
verses.text: One righteous man, then, differs not, as righteous, from another righteous man, whether he be of the Law or a Greek.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:27
verses.text: For God is not only Lord of the Jews, but of all men, and more nearly the Father of those who know Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:28
verses.text: For if to live well and according to the law is to live, also to live rationally according to the law is to live; and those who lived rightly before the Law were classed under faith, and judged to be righteous,—it is evident that those, too, who were outside of the Law, having lived rightly, in consequence of the peculiar nature of the voice, though they are in Hades and in ward, on hearing the voice of the Lord, whether that of His own person or that acting through His apostles, with all speed turned and believed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:29
verses.text: For we remember that the Lord is "the power of God," and power can never be weak.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:30
verses.text: So I think it is demonstrated that the God being good, and the Lord powerful, they save with a righteousness and equality which extend to all that turn to Him, whether here or elsewhere.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:31
verses.text: For it is not here alone that the active power of God is beforehand, but it is everywhere and is always at work.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:32
verses.text: Accordingly, in the Preaching of Peter, the Lord says to the disciples after the resurrection, "I have chosen you twelve disciples, judging you worthy of me," whom the Lord wished to be apostles, having judged them faithful, sending them into the world to the men on the earth, that they may know that there is one God, showing clearly what would take place by the faith of Christ; that they who heard and believed should be saved; and that those who believed not, after having heard, should bear witness, not having the excuse to allege, We have not heard.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:33
verses.text: What then? Did not the same dispensation obtain in Hades, so that even there, all the souls, on hearing the proclamation, might either exhibit repentance, or confess that their punishment was just, because they believed not? And it were the exercise of no ordinary arbitrariness, for those who had departed before the advent of the Lord (not having the Gospel preached to them, and having afforded no ground from themselves, in consequence of believing or not) to obtain either salvation or punishment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:34
verses.text: For it is not right that these should be condemned without trial, and that those alone who lived after the advent should have the advantage of the divine righteousness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:35
verses.text: But to all rational souls it was said from above, "Whatever one of you has done in ignorance, without clearly knowing God, if, on becoming conscious, he repent, all his sins will be forgiven him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:36
verses.text: "For, behold," it is said, "I have set before your face death and life, that ye may choose life".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:37
verses.text: God says that He set, not that He made both, in order to the comparison of choice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:38
verses.text: And in another Scripture He says, "If ye hear Me, and be willing, ye shall eat the good of the land.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:39
verses.text: But if ye hear Me not, and are not willing, the sword shall devour you: for the mouth of the Lord hath spoken these things".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:40
verses.text: Again, David expressly (or rather the Lord in the person of the saint, and the same from the foundation of the world is each one who at different periods is saved, and shall be saved by faith) says, "My heart was glad, and my tongue rejoiced, and my flesh shall still rest in hope.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:41
verses.text: For Thou shalt not leave my soul in hell, nor wilt Thou give Thine holy one to see corruption.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:42
verses.text: Thou hast made known to me the paths of life, Thou wilt make me full of joy in Thy presence".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:43
verses.text: As, then, the people was precious to the Lord, so also is the entire holy people; he also who is converted from the Gentiles, who was prophesied under the name of proselyte, along with the Jew.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:44
verses.text: For rightly the Scripture says, that "the ox and the bear shall come together".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:45
verses.text: For the Jew is designated by the ox, from the animal under the yoke being reckoned clean, according  to the law; for the ox both parts the hoof and chews the cud.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:46
verses.text: And the Gentile is designated by the bear, which is an unclean and wild beast.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:47
verses.text: And this animal brings forth a shapeless lump of flesh, which it shapes into the likeness of a beast solely by its tongue.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:48
verses.text: For he who is convened from among the Gentiles is formed from a beastlike life to gentleness by the word; and, when once tamed, is made clean, just as the ox.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:49
verses.text: For example, the prophet says, "The sirens, and the daughters of the sparrows, and all the beasts of the field, shall bless me".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:50
verses.text: Of the number of unclean animals, the wild beasts of the field are known to be, that is, of the world; since those who are wild in respect of faith, and polluted in life, and not purified by the righteousness which is according to the law, are called wild beasts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:51
verses.text: But changed from wild beasts by the faith of the Lord, they become men of God, advancing from the wish to change to the fact.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:52
verses.text: For some the Lord exhorts, and to those who have already made the attempt he stretches forth His hand, and draws them up.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:53
verses.text: "For the Lord dreads not the face of any one, nor will He regard greatness; for He hath made small and great, and cares alike for all".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:54
verses.text: And David says, "For the heathen are fixed in the destruction they have caused; their foot is taken in the snare which they hid".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:55
verses.text: "But the Lord was a refuge to the poor, a help in season also in affliction".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:56
verses.text: Those, then, that were in affliction had the Gospel seasonably proclaimed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:57
verses.text: And therefore it said, "Declare among the heathen his pursuits," that they may not be judged unjustly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:58
verses.text: If, then, He preached the Gospel to those in the flesh that they might not be condemned unjustly, how is it conceivable that He did not for the same cause preach the Gospel to those who had departed this life before His advent? "For the righteous Lord loveth righteousness: His countenance beholdeth uprightness".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:59
verses.text: "But he that loveth wickedness hateth his own soul".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:60
verses.text: If, then, in the deluge all sinful flesh perished, punishment having been inflicted on them for correction, we must first believe that the will of God, which is disciplinary and beneficent, saves those who turn to Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:61
verses.text: Then, too, the more subtle substance, the soul, could never receive any injury from the grosser element of water, its subtle and simple nature rendering it impalpable, called as it is incorporeal.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:62
verses.text: But whatever is gross, made so in consequence of sin, this is cast away along with the carnal spirit which lusts against the soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:63
verses.text: Now also Valentinus, the Coryphaeus of those who herald community, in his book on The Intercourse of Friends, writes in these words: "Many of the things that are written, though in common books, are found written in the church of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:64
verses.text: For those sayings which proceed from the heart are vain.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:65
verses.text: For the law written in the heart is the People of the Beloved—loved and loving Him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:66
verses.text: For whether it be the Jewish writings or those of the philosophers that he calls "the Common Books," he makes the truth common.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:67
verses.text: And Isidore, at once son and disciple to Basilides, in the first book of the Expositions of the Prophet Parchor, writes also in these words: "The Attics say that certain things were intimated to Socrates, in consequence of a daemon attending on him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:68
verses.text: And Aristotle says that all men are provided with daemons, that attend on them during the time they are in the body,—having taken this piece of prophetic instruction and transferred it to his own books, without acknowledging whence he had abstracted this statement".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:69
verses.text: And again, in the second book of his work, he thus writes: "And let no one think that what we say is peculiar to the elect, was said before by any philosophers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:70
verses.text: For it is not a discovery of theirs.
