verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:71
verses.text: For having appropriated it from our prophets, they attributed it to him who is wise according to them".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 6:72
verses.text: Again, in the same: "For to me it appears that those who profess to philosophize, do so that they may learn what is the winged oak, and the variegated robe on it, all of which Pherecydes has employed as theological allegories, having taken them from the prophecy of Cham".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:1
verses.text: Chapter 7—What True Philosophy Is, and Whence So Called.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:2
verses.text: As we have long ago pointed out, what we propose as our subject is not the discipline which obtains in each sect, but that which is really philosophy, strictly systematic Wisdom, which furnishes acquaintance with the things which pertain to life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:3
verses.text: And we define Wisdom to be certain knowledge, being a sure and irrefragable apprehension of things divine and human, comprehending the present, past, and future, which the Lord hath taught us, both by His advent and by the prophets.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:4
verses.text: And it is irrefragable by reason, inasmuch as it has been communicated.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:5
verses.text: And so it is wholly true according to God's intention, as being known through means of the Son.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:6
verses.text: And in one aspect it is eternal, and in another it becomes useful in time.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:7
verses.text: Partly it is one and the same, partly many and indifferent—partly without any movement of passion, partly with passionate desire—partly perfect, partly incomplete.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:8
verses.text: This wisdom, then—rectitude of soul and of reason, and purity of life—is the object of the desire of philosophy, which is kindly and lovingly disposed towards wisdom, and does everything to attain it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:9
verses.text: Now those are called philosophers, among us, who love Wisdom, the Creator and Teacher of all things, that is, the knowledge of the Son of God; and among the Greeks, those who undertake arguments on virtue.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:10
verses.text: Philosophy, then, consists of such dogmas found in each sect (I mean those of philosophy) as cannot be impugned, with a corresponding life, collected into one selection; and these, stolen from the Barbarian God-given grace, have been adorned by Greek speech.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:11
verses.text: For some they have borrowed, and others they have misunderstood.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:12
verses.text: And in the case of others, what they have spoken, in consequence of being moved, they have not yet perfectly worked out; and others by human conjecture and reasoning, in which also they stumble.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:13
verses.text: And they think that they have hit the truth perfectly; but as we understand them, only partially.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:14
verses.text: They know, then, nothing more than this world.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:15
verses.text: And it is just like geometry, which treats of measures and magnitudes and forms, by delineation on plane-surfaces; and just as painting appears to take in the whole field of view in the scenes represented.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:16
verses.text: But it gives a false description of the view, according to the rules of the art, employing the signs that result from the incidents of the lines of vision.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:17
verses.text: By this means, the higher and lower points in the view, and those between, are preserved; and some objects seem to appear in the foreground, and others in the background, and others to appear in some other way, on the smooth and level surface.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:18
verses.text: So also the philosophers copy the truth, after the manner of painting.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:19
verses.text: And always in the case of each one of them, their self-love is the cause of all their mistakes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:20
verses.text: Wherefore one ought not, in the desire for the glory that terminates in men, to be animated by self-love; but loving God, to become really holy with wisdom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:21
verses.text: If, then, one treats what is particular as universal, and regards that, which serves, as the Lord, he misses the truth, not understanding what was spoken by David by way of confession: "I have eaten earth ashes like bread".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:22
verses.text: Now, self-love and self-conceit are, in his view, earth and error.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:23
verses.text: But if so, science and knowledge are derived from instruction.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:24
verses.text: And if there is instruction, you must seek for the master.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:25
verses.text: Cleanthes claims Zeno, and Metrodorus Epicurus, and Theophrastus Aristotle, and Plato Socrates.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:26
verses.text: But if I come to Pythagoras, and Pherecydes, and Thales, and the first wise men, I come to a stand in my search for their teacher.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:27
verses.text: Should you say the Egyptians, the Indians, the Babylonians, and the Magi themselves, I will not stop from asking their teacher.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:28
verses.text: And I lead you up to the first generation of men; and from that point I begin to investigate Who is their teacher.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:29
verses.text: No one of men; for they had not yet learned.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:30
verses.text: Nor yet any of the angels: for in the way that angels, in virtue of being angels, speak, men do not hear; nor, as we have ears, have they a tongue to correspond; nor would any one attribute to the angels organs of speech, lips I mean, and the parts contiguous, throat, and windpipe, and chest, breath and air to vibrate.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:31
verses.text: And God is far from calling aloud in the unapproachable sanctity, separated as He is from even the archangels.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:32
verses.text: And we also have already heard that angels learned the truth, and their rulers over them; for they had a beginning.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:33
verses.text: It remains, then, for us, ascending to seek their teacher.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:34
verses.text: And since the unoriginated Being is one, the Omnipotent God; one, too, is the First-begotten, "by whom all things were made, and without whom not one thing ever was made".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:35
verses.text: "For one, in truth, is God, who formed the beginning of all things;" pointing out "the first-begotten Son," Peter writes, accurately comprehending the statement, "In the beginning God made the heaven and the earth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:36
verses.text: And He is called Wisdom by all the prophets.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:37
verses.text: This is He who is the Teacher of all created beings, the Fellow-counsellor of God, who foreknew all things; and He from above, from the first foundation of the world, "in many ways and many times," trains and perfects; whence it is rightly said, "Call no man your teacher on earth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:38
verses.text: You see whence the true philosophy has its handles; though the Law be the image and shadow of the truth: for the Law is the shadow of the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:39
verses.text: But the self-love of the Greeks proclaims certain men as their teachers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:40
verses.text: As, then, the whole family runs back to God the Creator; so also all the teaching of good things, which justifies, does to the Lord, and leads and contributes to this.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:41
verses.text: But if from any creature they received in any way whatever the seeds of the Truth, they did not nourish them; but committing them to a barren and rainless soil, they choked them with weeds, as the Pharisees revolted from the Law, by introducing human teachings,—the cause of these being not the Teacher, but those who choose to disobey.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:42
verses.text: But those of them who believed the Lord's advent and the plain teaching of the Scriptures, attain to the knowledge of the law; as also those addicted to philosophy, by the teaching of the Lord, are introduced into the knowledge of the true philosophy: "For the oracles of the Lord are pure oracles, melted in the fire, tried in the earth, purified seven times".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:43
verses.text: Just as silver often purified, so is the just man brought to the test, becoming the Lord's coin and receiving the royal image.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:44
verses.text: Or, since Solomon also calls the "tongue of the righteous man gold that has been subjected to fire," intimating that the doctrine which has been proved, and is wise, is to be praised and received, whenever it is amply tried by the earth: that is, when the gnostic soul is in manifold ways sanctified, through withdrawal from earthy fires.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:45
verses.text: And the body in which it dwells is purified, being appropriated to the pureness of a holy temple.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:46
verses.text: But the first purification which takes place in the body, the soul being first, is abstinence from evil things, which some consider perfection, and is, in truth, the perfection of the common believer—Jew and Greek.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:47
verses.text: But in the case of the Gnostic, after that which is reckoned perfection in others, his righteousness advances to activity in well-doing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:48
verses.text: And in whomsoever the increased force of righteousness advances to the doing of good, in his case perfection abides in the fixed habit of well-doing after the likeness of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:49
verses.text: For those who are the seed of Abraham, and besides servants of God, are "the called;" and the sons of Jacob are the elect—they who have tripped up the energy of wickedness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:50
verses.text: If; then, we assert that Christ Himself is Wisdom, and that it was His working which showed itself in the prophets, by which the gnostic tradition may be learned, as He Himself taught the apostles during His presence; then it follows that the gnosis, which is the knowledge and apprehension of things present, future, and past, which is sure and reliable, as being imparted and revealed by the Son of God, is wisdom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:51
verses.text: And if, too, the end of the wise man is contemplation, that of those who are still philosophers aims at it, but never attains it, unless by the process of learning it receives the prophetic utterance which has been made known, by which it grasps both the present, the future, and the past—how they are, were, and shall be.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:52
verses.text: And the gnosis itself is that which has descended by transmission to a few, having been imparted unwritten by the apostles.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 7:53
verses.text: Hence, then, knowledge or wisdom ought to be exercised up to the eternal and unchangeable habit of contemplation.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:1
verses.text: Chapter 8—Philosophy is Knowledge Given by God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:2
verses.text: For Paul too, in the Epistles, plainly does not disparage philosophy; but deems it unworthy of the man who has attained to the elevation of the Gnostic, any more to go back to the Hellenic "philosophy," figuratively calling it "the rudiments of this world," as being most rudimentary, and a preparatory training for the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:3
verses.text: Wherefore also, writing to the Hebrews, who were declining again from faith to the law, he says, "Have ye not need again of one to teach you which are the first principles of the oracles of God, and are become such as have need of milk, and not of strong meat?" So also to the Colossians, who were Greek converts, "Beware lest any man spoil you by philosophy and vain deceit, after the tradition of men, after the rudiments of this world, and not after Christ,"—enticing them again to return to philosophy, the elementary doctrine.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:4
verses.text: And should one say that it was through human understanding that philosophy was discovered by the Greeks, still I find the Scriptures saying that understanding is sent by God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:5
verses.text: The psalmist, accordingly, considers understanding as the greatest free gift, and beseeches, saying, "I am Thy servant; give me understanding".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:6
verses.text: And does not David, while asking the abundant experience of knowledge, write, "Teach me gentleness, and discipline, and knowledge: for I have believed in Thy commandments?" He confessed the covenants to be of the highest authority, and that they were given to the more excellent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:7
verses.text: Accordingly the psalm again says of God, "He hath not done thus to any nation; and He hath not shown His judgments to them".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:8
verses.text: The expression "He hath not done so" shows that He hath done, but not "thus".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:9
verses.text: The "thus," then, is put comparatively, with reference to pre-eminence, which obtains in our case.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:10
verses.text: The prophet might have said simply, "He hath not done," without the "thus".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:11
verses.text: Further, Peter in the Acts says, "Of a truth, I perceive that God is no respecter of persons; but in every nation he that feareth Him, and worketh righteousness, is accepted by Him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:12
verses.text: The absence of respect of persons in God is not then in time, but from eternity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:13
verses.text: Nor had His beneficence a beginning; nor any more is it limited to places or persons.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:14
verses.text: For His beneficence is not confined to parts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:15
verses.text: "Open ye the gates of righteousness," it is said; "entering into them, I will confess to the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:16
verses.text: This is the gate of the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:17
verses.text: The righteous shall enter by it".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:18
verses.text: Explaining the prophet's saying, Barnabas adds, "There being many gates open, that which is in righteousness is the gate which is in Christ, by which all who enter are blessed".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:19
verses.text: Bordering on the same meaning is also the following prophetic utterance: "The Lord is on many waters;" not the different covenants alone, but the modes of teaching, those among the Greek and those among the Barbarians, conducing to righteousness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:20
verses.text: And already clearly David, bearing testimony to the truth, sings, "Let sinners be turned into Hades, and all the nations that forget God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:21
verses.text: They forget, plainly, Him whom they formerly remembered, and dismiss Him whom they knew previous to forgetting Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:22
verses.text: There was then a dim knowledge of God also among the nations.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:23
verses.text: So much for those points.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:24
verses.text: Now the Gnostic must be erudite.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:25
verses.text: And since the Greeks say that Protagoras having led the way, the opposing of one argument by another was invented, it is fitting that something be said with reference to arguments of this sort.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:26
verses.text: For Scripture says, "He that says much, shall also hear in his turn".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:27
verses.text: And who shall understand a parable of the Lord, but the wise, the intelligent, and he that loves his Lord? Let such a man be faithful; let him be capable of uttering his knowledge; let him be wise in the discrimination of words; let him be dexterous in action; let him be pure.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:28
verses.text: "The greater he seems to be, the more humble should he be," says Clement in the Epistle to the Corinthians,—"such an one as is capable of complying with the precept, 'And some pluck from the fire, and on others have compassion, making a difference,'"  The pruning-hook is made, certainly, principally for pruning; but with it we separate twigs that have got intertwined, cut the thorns which grow along with the vines, which it is not very easy to reach.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:29
verses.text: And all these things have a reference to pruning.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:30
verses.text: Again, man is made principally for the knowledge of God; but he also measures land, practices agriculture, and philosophizes; of which pursuits, one conduces to life, another to living well, a third to the study of the things which are capable of demonstration.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:31
verses.text: Further, let those who say that philosophy took its rise from the devil know this, that the Scripture says that "the devil is transformed into an angel of light".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:32
verses.text: When about to do what? Plainly, when about to prophesy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:33
verses.text: But if he prophesies as an angel of light, he will speak what is true.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:34
verses.text: And if he prophesies what is angelical, and of the light, then he prophesies what is beneficial when he is transformed according to the likeness of the operation, though he be different with respect to the matter of apostasy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:35
verses.text: For how could he deceive any one, without drawing the lover of knowledge into fellowship, and so drawing him afterwards into falsehood? Especially he will be found to know the truth, if not so as to comprehend it, yet so as not to be unacquainted with it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:36
verses.text: Philosophy is not then false, though the thief and the liar speak truth, through a transformation of operation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:37
verses.text: Nor is sentence of condemnation to be pronounced ignorantly against what is said, on account of him who says it (which also is to be kept in view, in the case of those who are now alleged to prophesy); but what is said must be looked at, to see if it keep by the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:38
verses.text: And in general terms, we shall not err in alleging that all things necessary and profitable for life came to us from God, and that philosophy more especially was given to the Greeks, as a covenant peculiar to them—being, as it is, a stepping-stone to the philosophy which is according to Christ—although those who applied themselves to the philosophy of the Greeks shut their ears voluntarily to the truth, despising the voice of Barbarians, or also dreading the danger suspended over the believer, by the laws of the state.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:39
verses.text: And as in the Barbarian philosophy, so also in the Hellenic, "tares were sown" by the proper husbandman of the tares; whence also heresies grew up among us along with the productive wheat; and those who in the Hellenic philosophy preach the impiety and voluptuousness of Epicurus, and whatever other tenets are disseminated contrary to right reason, exist among the Greeks as spurious fruits of the divinely bestowed husbandry.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:40
verses.text: This voluptuous and selfish philosophy the apostle calls "the wisdom of this world;" in consequence of its teaching the things of this world and about it alone, and its consequent subjection, as far as respects ascendancy, to those who rule here.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:41
verses.text: Wherefore also this fragmentary philosophy is very elementary, while truly perfect science deals with intellectual objects, which are beyond the sphere of the world, and with the objects still more spiritual than those which "eye saw not, and ear heard not, nor did it enter into the heart of men," till the Teacher told the account of them to us;  unveiling the holy of holies; and in ascending order, things still holier than these, to those who are truly and not spuriously heirs of the Lord's adoption.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:42
verses.text: For we now dare aver (for here is the faith that is characterized by knowledge) that such an one knows all things, and comprehends all things in the exercise of sure apprehension, respecting matters difficult for us, and really pertaining to the true gnosis such as were James, Peter, John, Paul, and the rest of the apostles.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:43
verses.text: For prophecy is full of knowledge (gnosis), inasmuch as it was given by the Lord, and again explained by the Lord to the apostles.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:44
verses.text: And is not knowledge (gnosis) an attribute of the rational soul, which trains itself for this, that by knowledge it may become entitled to immortality? For both are powers of the soul, both knowledge and impulse.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:45
verses.text: And impulse is found to be a movement after an assent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:46
verses.text: For he who has an impulse towards an action, first receives the knowledge of the action, and secondly the impulse.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:47
verses.text: Let us further devote our attention to this.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:48
verses.text: For since learning is older than action; (for naturally, he who does what he wishes to do learns it first; and knowledge comes from learning, and impulse follows knowledge; after which comes action;) knowledge turns out the beginning and author of all rational action.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:49
verses.text: So that rightly the peculiar nature of the rational soul is characterized by this alone; for in reality impulse, like knowledge, is excited by existing objects.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:50
verses.text: And knowledge (gnosis) is essentially a contemplation of existences on the part of the soul, either of a certain thing or of certain things, and when perfected, of all together.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:51
verses.text: Although some say that the wise man is persuaded that there are some things incomprehensible, in such wise as to have respecting them a kind of comprehension, inasmuch as he comprehends that things incomprehensible are incomprehensible; which is common, and pertains to those who are capable of perceiving little.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:52
verses.text: For such a man affirms that there are some things incomprehensible.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:53
verses.text: But that Gnostic of whom I speak, himself comprehends what seems to be incomprehensible to others; believing that nothing is incomprehensible to the Son of God, whence nothing incapable of being taught.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:54
verses.text: For He who suffered out of His love for us, would have suppressed no element of knowledge requisite for our instruction.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:55
verses.text: Accordingly this faith becomes sure demonstration; since truth follows what has been delivered by God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:56
verses.text: But if one desires extensive knowledge, "he knows things ancient, and conjectures things future; he understands knotty sayings, and the solutions of enigmas.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 8:57
verses.text: The disciple of wisdom foreknows signs and omens, and the issues of seasons and of times".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:1
verses.text: Chapter 9—The Gnostic Free of All Perturbations of the Soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:2
verses.text: The Gnostic is such, that he is subject only to the affections that exist for the maintenance of the body, such as hunger, thirst, and the like.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:3
verses.text: But in the case of the Saviour, it were ludicrous to suppose that the body, as a body, demanded the necessary aids in order to its duration.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:4
verses.text: For He ate, not for the sake of the body, which was kept together by a holy energy, but in order that it might not enter into the minds of those who were with Him to entertain a different opinion of Him; in like manner as certainly some afterwards supposed that He appeared in a phantasmal shape (δοκήσει).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:5
verses.text: But He was entirely impassible (ἀπαθής); inaccessible to any movement of feeling—either pleasure or pain.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:6
verses.text: While the apostles, having most gnostically mastered, through the Lord's teaching, anger and fear, and lust, were not liable even to such of the movements of feeling, as seem good, courage, zeal, joy, desire, through a steady condition of mind, not changing a whit; but ever continuing unvarying in a state of training after the resurrection of the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:7
verses.text: And should it be granted that the affections specified above, when produced rationally, are good, yet they are nevertheless inadmissible in the case of the perfect man, who is incapable of exercising courage: for neither does he meet what inspires fear, as he regards none of the things that occur in life as to be dreaded; nor can aught dislodge him from this—the love he has towards God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:8
verses.text: Nor does he need cheerfulness of mind; for he does not fall into pain, being persuaded that all things happen well.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:9
verses.text: Nor is he angry; for there is nothing to move him to anger, seeing he ever loves God, and is entirely turned towards Him alone, and therefore hates none of God's creatures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:10
verses.text: No more does he envy; for nothing is wanting to him, that is requisite to assimilation, in order that he may be excellent and good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:11
verses.text: Nor does he consequently love any one with this common affection, but loves the Creator in the creatures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:12
verses.text: Nor, consequently, does he fall into any desire and eagerness; nor does he want, as far as respects his soul, aught appertaining to others, now that he associates through love with the Beloved One, to whom he is allied by free choice, and by the habit which results from training, approaches closer to Him, and is blessed through the abundance of good things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:13
verses.text: So that on these accounts he is compelled to  become like his Teacher in impassibility.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:14
verses.text: For the Word of God is intellectual, according as the image of mind is seen in man alone.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:15
verses.text: Thus also the good man is godlike in form and semblance as respects his soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:16
verses.text: And, on the other hand, God is like man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:17
verses.text: For the distinctive form of each one is the mind by which we are characterized.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:18
verses.text: Consequently, also, those who sin against man are unholy and impious.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:19
verses.text: For it were ridiculous to say that the gnostic and perfect man must not eradicate anger and courage, inasmuch as without these he will not struggle against circumstances, or abide what is terrible.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:20
verses.text: But if we take from him desire, he will be quite overwhelmed by troubles, and therefore depart from this life very basely.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:21
verses.text: Unless possessed of it, as some suppose, he will not conceive a desire for what is like the excellent and the good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:22
verses.text: If, then, all alliance with what is good is accompanied with desire, how, it is said, does he remain impassible who desires what is excellent?  But these people know not, as appears, the divinity of love.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:23
verses.text: For love is not desire on the part of him who loves; but is a relation of affection, restoring the Gnostic to the unity of the faith,—independent of time and place.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:24
verses.text: But he who by love is already in the midst of that in which he is destined to be, and has anticipated hope by knowledge, does not desire anything, having, as far as possible, the very thing desired.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:25
verses.text: Accordingly, as to be expected, he continues in the exercise of gnostic love, in the one unvarying state.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:26
verses.text: Nor will he, therefore, eagerly desire to be assimilated to what is beautiful, possessing, as he does, beauty by love.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:27
verses.text: What more need of courage and of desire to him, who has obtained the affinity to the impassible God which arises from love, and by love has enrolled himself among the friends of God?  We must therefore rescue the gnostic and perfect man from all passion of the soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:28
verses.text: For knowledge (gnosis) produces practice, and practice habit or disposition; and such a state as this produces impassibility, not moderation of passion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:29
verses.text: And the complete eradication of desire reaps as its fruit impassibility.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:30
verses.text: But the Gnostic does not share either in those affections that are commonly celebrated as good, that is, the good things of the affections which are allied to the passions: such, I mean, as gladness, which is allied to pleasure; and dejection, for this is conjoined with pain; and caution, for it is subject to fear.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:31
verses.text: Nor yet does he share in high spirit, for it takes its place alongside of wrath; although some say that these are no longer evil, but already good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:32
verses.text: For it is impossible that he who has been once made perfect by love, and feasts eternally and insatiably on the boundless joy of contemplation, should delight in small and grovelling things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:33
verses.text: For what rational cause remains any more to the man who has gained "the light inaccessible," for revering to the good things of the world? Although not yet true as to time and place, yet by that gnostic love through which the inheritance and perfect restitution follow, the giver of the reward makes good by deeds what the Gnostic, by gnostic choice, had grasped by anticipation through love.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:34
verses.text: For by going away to the Lord, for the love he bears Him, though his tabernacle be visible on earth, he does not withdraw himself from life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:35
verses.text: For that is not permitted to him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:36
verses.text: But he has withdrawn his soul from the passions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:37
verses.text: For that is granted to him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:38
verses.text: And on the other hand he lives, having put to death his lusts, and no longer makes use of the body, but allows it the use of necessaries, that he may not give cause for dissolution.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:39
verses.text: How, then, has he any more need of fortitude, who is not in the midst of dangers, being not present, but already wholly with the object of love? And what necessity for self-restraint to him who has not need of it? For to have such desires, as require self-restraint in order to their control, is characteristic of one who is not yet pure, but subject to passion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:40
verses.text: Now, fortitude is assumed by reason of fear and cowardice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:41
verses.text: For it were no longer seemly that the friend of God, whom "God hath fore-ordained before the foundation of the world" to be enrolled in the highest "adoption," should fall into pleasures or fears, and be occupied in the repression of the passions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:42
verses.text: For I venture to assert, that as he is predestinated through what he shall do, and what he shall obtain, so also has he predestinated himself by reason of what he knew and whom he loved; not having the future indistinct, as the multitude live, conjecturing it, but having grasped by gnostic faith what is hidden from others.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:43
verses.text: And through love, the future is for him already present.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:44
verses.text: For he has believed, through prophecy and the advent, on God who lies not.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:45
verses.text: And what he believes he possesses, and keeps hold of the promise.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:46
verses.text: And He who hath promised is truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:47
verses.text: And through the trustworthiness of Him who has promised, he has firmly laid hold of the end of the promise by knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:48
verses.text: And he, who knows the sure comprehension of the future which there is in the circumstances, in which he is placed, by love goes to meet the future.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:49
verses.text: So he, that is persuaded that he will obtain the things that are really good, will not pray to obtain what is here, but that he may always cling to the faith which hits the mark and succeeds.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:50
verses.text: And besides, he will pray that as many as possible may become like him, to the glory of God,  which is perfected through knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:51
verses.text: For he who is made like the Saviour is also devoted to saving; performing unerringly the commandments as far as the human nature may admit of the image.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:52
verses.text: And this is to worship God by deeds and knowledge of the true righteousness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:53
verses.text: The Lord will not wait for the voice of this man in prayer.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:54
verses.text: "Ask," He says, "and I will do it; think, and I will give".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:55
verses.text: For, in fine, it is impossible that the immutable should assume firmness and consistency in the mutable.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:56
verses.text: But the ruling faculty being in perpetual change, and therefore unstable, the force of habit is not maintained.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:57
verses.text: For how can he who is perpetually changed by external occurrences and accidents, ever possess habit and disposition, and in a word, grasp of scientific knowledge (ἐπιστήμη)? Further, also, the philosophers regard the virtues as habits, dispositions, and sciences.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:58
verses.text: And as knowledge (gnosis) is not born with men, but is acquired, and the acquiring of it in its elements demands application, and training, and progress; and then from incessant practice it passes into a habit; so, when perfected in the mystic habit, it abides, being infallible through love.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:59
verses.text: For not only has he apprehended the first Cause, and the Cause produced by it, and is sure about them, possessing firmly firm and irrefragable and immoveable reasons; but also respecting what is good and what is evil, and respecting all production, and to speak comprehensively, respecting all about which the Lord has spoken, he has learned, from the truth itself, the most exact truth from the foundation of the world to the end.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:60
verses.text: Not preferring to the truth itself what appears plausible, or, according to Hellenic reasoning, necessary; but what has been spoken by the Lord he accepts as clear and evident, though concealed from others; and he has already received the knowledge of all things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:61
verses.text: And the oracles we possess give their utterances respecting what exists, as it is; and respecting what is future, as it shall be; and respecting what is past, as it was.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:62
verses.text: In scientific matters, as being alone possessed of scientific knowledge, he will hold the preeminence, and will discourse on the discussion respecting the good, ever intent on intellectual objects, tracing out his procedure in human affairs from the archetypes above; as navigators direct the ship according to the star; prepared to hold himself in readiness for every suitable action; accustomed to despise all difficulties and dangers when it is necessary to undergo them; never doing anything precipitate or incongruous either to himself or the common weal; foreseeing; and inflexible by pleasures both of waking hours and of dreams.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:63
verses.text: For, accustomed to spare living and frugality, he is moderate, active, and grave; requiring few necessaries for life; occupying himself with nothing superfluous.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 9:64
verses.text: But desiring not even these things as chief, but by reason of fellowship in life, as necessary for his sojourn in life, as far as necessary.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:1
verses.text: Chapter 10—The Gnostic Avails Himself of the Help of All Human Knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:2
verses.text: For to him knowledge (gnosis) is the principal thing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:3
verses.text: Consequently, therefore, he applies to the subjects that are a training for knowledge, taking from each branch of study its contribution to the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:4
verses.text: Prosecuting, then, the proportion of harmonies in music; and in arithmetic noting the increasing and decreasing of numbers, and their relations to one another, and how the most of things fall under some proportion of numbers; studying geometry, which is abstract essence, he perceives a continuous distance, and an immutable essence which is different from these bodies.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:5
verses.text: And by astronomy, again, raised from the earth in his mind, he is elevated along with heaven, and will revolve with its revolution; studying ever divine things, and their harmony with each other; from which Abraham starting, ascended to the knowledge of Him who created them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:6
verses.text: Further, the Gnostic will avail himself of dialectics, fixing on the distinction of genera into species, and will master the distinction of existences, till he come to what are primary and simple.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:7
verses.text: But the multitude are frightened at the Hellenic philosophy, as children are at masks, being afraid lest it lead them astray.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:8
verses.text: But if the faith (for I cannot call it knowledge) which they possess be such as to be dissolved by plausible speech, let it be by all means dissolved, and let them confess that they will not retain the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:9
verses.text: For truth is immoveable; but false opinion dissolves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:10
verses.text: We choose, for instance, one purple by comparison with another purple.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:11
verses.text: So that, if one confesses that he has not a heart that has been made right, he has not the table of the money-changers or the test of words.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:12
verses.text: And how can he be any longer a money-changer, who is not able to prove and distinguish spurious coin, even offhand?  Now David cried, "The righteous shall not be shaken for ever;" neither, consequently, by deceptive speech nor by erring pleasure.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:13
verses.text: Whence he shall never be shaken from his own heritage.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:14
verses.text: "He shall not be afraid of evil tidings;" consequently neither of unfounded calumny, nor of the false opinion around him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:15
verses.text: No more will he dread cunning words, who is capable of distinguishing them, or of answering rightly to questions asked.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:16
verses.text: Such a bulwark are dialectics, that truth cannot be trampled under foot by the Sophists.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:17
verses.text: "For it behoves those who praise in the holy name of the Lord," according to the prophet, "to rejoice in heart, seeking the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:18
verses.text: Seek then Him, and be strong.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:19
verses.text: Seek His face continually in every way".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:20
verses.text: "For, having spoken at sundry times and in divers manners," it is not in one way only that He is known.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:21
verses.text: It is, then, not by availing himself of these as virtues that our Gnostic will be deeply learned.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:22
verses.text: But by using them as helps in distinguishing what is common and what is peculiar, he will admit the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:23
verses.text: For the cause of all error and false opinion, is inability to distinguish in what respect things are common, and in what respects they differ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:24
verses.text: For unless, in things that are distinct, one closely watch speech, he will inadvertently confound what is common and what is peculiar.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:25
verses.text: And where this takes place, he must of necessity fall into pathless tracts and error.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:26
verses.text: The distinction of names and things also in the Scriptures themselves produces great light in men's souls.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:27
verses.text: For it is necessary to understand expressions which signify several things, and several expressions when they signify one thing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:28
verses.text: The result of which is accurate answering.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:29
verses.text: But it is necessary to avoid the great futility which occupies itself in irrelevant matters; since the Gnostic avails himself of branches of learning as auxiliary preparatory exercises, in order to the accurate communication of the truth, as far as attainable and with as little distraction as possible, and for defence against reasonings that plot for the extinction of the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:30
verses.text: He will not then be deficient in what contributes to proficiency in the curriculum of studies and the Hellenic philosophy; but not principally, but necessarily, secondarily, and on account of circumstances.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:31
verses.text: For what those labouring in heresies use wickedly, the Gnostic will use rightly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:32
verses.text: Therefore the truth that appears in the Hellenic philosophy, being partial, the real truth, like the sun glancing on the colours both white and black, shows what like each of them is.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:33
verses.text: So also it exposes all sophistical plausibility.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 10:34
verses.text: Rightly, then, was it proclaimed also by the Greeks:—"Truth the queen is the beginning of great virtue".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:1
verses.text: Chapter 11—The Mystical Meanings in the Proportions of Numbers, Geometrical Ratios, and Music.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:2
verses.text: As then in astronomy we have Abraham as an instance, so also in arithmetic we have the same Abraham.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:3
verses.text: "For, hearing that Lot was taken captive, and having numbered his own servants, born in his house,  (τιὴ)," he defeats a very great number of the enemy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:4
verses.text: They say, then, that the character representing  is, as to shape, the type of the Lord's sign, and that the Iota and the Eta indicate the Saviour's name; that it was indicated, accordingly, that Abraham's domestics were in salvation, who having fled to the Sign and the Name became lords of the captives, and of the very many unbelieving nations that followed them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:5
verses.text: Now the number  is,  by.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:6
verses.text: Ten is allowed to be the perfect number.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:7
verses.text: And  is the first cube, which is equality in all the dimensions—length, breadth, depth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:8
verses.text: "The days of men shall be," it is said, " (ρκ´) years".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:9
verses.text: And the sum is made up of the numbers from  to  added together.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:10
verses.text: And the moon at  days is full.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:11
verses.text: On another principle,  is a triangular number, and consists of the equality of the number , which consists of eight of the odd numbers beginning with unity, the addition of which (, , , , , , , ) in succession generate squares; and of the inequality of the number , consisting of seven of the even numbers beginning with  (, , , , , , ), which produce the numbers that are not squares  Again, according to another way of indicating, the number  consists of four numbers—of one triangle, ; of another, a square, ; of a third, a pentagon, ; and of a fourth, a hexagon,.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:12
verses.text: The  is taken according to the same ratio in each mode.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:13
verses.text: For in triangular numbers, from the unity  comes ; and in squares, ; and of those in succession, proportionally.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:14
verses.text: Now , which is the number  from unity, is said to be the symbol of the Levitical tribe.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:15
verses.text: And the  number  depends also on the arithmetic, geometric, and harmonic scale of doubles—, , , ; the addition of which makes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:16
verses.text: In these days, the Jews say that seven months' children are formed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:17
verses.text: And the number  depends on the scale of triples—, , , —the addition of which makes ; and similarly, in these days they say that nine months' children are formed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:18
verses.text: Such, then, is the style of the example in arithmetic.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:19
verses.text: And let the testimony of geometry be the tabernacle that was constructed, and the ark that was fashioned,—constructed in most regular proportions, and through divine ideas, by the gift of understanding, which leads us from things of sense to intellectual objects, or rather from these to holy things, and to the holy of holies.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:20
verses.text: For the squares of wood indicate that the square form, producing right angles, pervades all, and points out security.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:21
verses.text: And the length of the structure was three hundred cubits, and the breadth fifty, and the height thirty; and above, the ark ends in a cubit, narrowing to a cubit from the broad base like a pyramid, the symbol of those who are purified and tested by fire.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:22
verses.text: And this geometrical proportion has a place, for the transport of those holy abodes, whose differences are indicated by the differences of the numbers set down below.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:23
verses.text: And the numbers introduced are sixfold, as three hundred is six times fifty; and tenfold, as three hundred is ten times thirty; and containing one and two-thirds (επιδίμοιροι), for fifty is one and two-thirds of thirty.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:24
verses.text: Now there are some who say that three hundred cubits are the symbol of the Lord's sign; and fifty, of hope and of the remission given at Pentecost; and thirty, or as in some, twelve, they say points out the preaching of the Gospel; because the Lord preached in His thirtieth year; and the apostles were twelve.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:25
verses.text: And the structure's terminating in a cubit is the symbol of the advancement of the righteous to oneness and to "the unity of the faith".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:26
verses.text: And the table which was in the temple was six cubits; and its four feet were about a cubit and a half.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:27
verses.text: They add, then, the twelve cubits, agreeably to the revolution of the twelve months, in the annual circle, during which the earth produces and matures all things; adapting itself to the four seasons.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:28
verses.text: And the table, in my opinion, exhibits the image of the earth, supported as it is on four feet, summer, autumn, spring, winter, by which the year travels.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:29
verses.text: Wherefore also it is said that the table has "wavy chains;" either because the universe revolves in the circuits of the times, or perhaps it indicated the earth surrounded with ocean's tide.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:30
verses.text: Further, as an example of music, let us adduce David, playing at once and prophesying, melodiously praising God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:31
verses.text: Now the Enarmonic suits best the Dorian harmony, and the Diatonic the Phrygian, as Aristoxenus says.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:32
verses.text: The harmony, therefore, of the Barbarian psaltery, which exhibited gravity of strain, being the most ancient, most certainly became a model for Terpander, for the Dorian harmony, who sings the praise of Zeus thus:—  "O Zeus, of all things the Beginning, Ruler of all; O Zeus, I send thee this beginning of hymns".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:33
verses.text: The lyre, according to its primary signification, may by the psalmist be used figuratively for the Lord; according to its secondary, for those who continually strike the chords of their souls under the direction of the Choir-master, the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:34
verses.text: And if the people saved be called the lyre, it will be understood to be in consequence of their giving glory musically, through the inspiration of the Word and the knowledge of God, being struck by the Word so as to produce faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:35
verses.text: You may take music in another way, as the ecclesiastical symphony at once of the law and the prophets, and the apostles along with the Gospel, and the harmony which obtained in each prophet, in the transitions of the persons.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:36
verses.text: But, as seems, the most of those who are inscribed with the Name, like the companions of Ulysses, handle the word unskilfully, passing by not the Sirens, but the rhythm and the melody, stopping their ears with ignorance; since they know that, after lending their ears to Hellenic studies, they will never subsequently be able to retrace their steps.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:37
verses.text: But he who culls what is useful for the advantage of the catechumens, and especially when they are Greeks (and the earth is the Lord's, and the fulness thereof), must not abstain from erudition, like irrational animals; but he must collect as many aids as possible for his hearers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:38
verses.text: But he must by no means linger over these studies, except solely for the advantage accruing from them; so that, on grasping and obtaining this, he may be able to take his departure home to the true philosophy, which is a strong cable for the soul, providing security from everything.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:39
verses.text: Music is then to be handled for the sake of the embellishment and composure of manners.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:40
verses.text: For instance, at a banquet we pledge each other while the music is playing; soothing by song the eagerness of our desires, and glorifying God  for the copious gift of human enjoyments, for His perpetual supply of the food necessary for the growth of the body and of the soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:41
verses.text: But we must reject superfluous music, which enervates men's souls, and leads to variety,—now mournful, and then licentious and voluptuous, and then frenzied and frantic.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:42
verses.text: The same holds also of astronomy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:43
verses.text: For treating of the description of the celestial objects, about the form of the universe, and the revolution of the heavens, and the motion of the stars, leading the soul nearer to the creative power, it teaches to quickness in perceiving the seasons of the year, the changes of the air, and the appearance of the stars; since also navigation and husbandry derive from this much benefit, as architecture and building from geometry.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:44
verses.text: This branch of learning, too, makes the soul in the highest degree observant, capable of perceiving the true and detecting the false, of discovering correspondences and proportions, so as to hunt out for similarity in things dissimilar; and conducts us to the discovery of length without breadth, and superficial extent without thickness, and an indivisible point, and transports to intellectual objects from those of sense.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:45
verses.text: The studies of philosophy, therefore, and philosophy itself, are aids in treating of the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:46
verses.text: For instance, the cloak was once a fleece; then it was shorn, and became warp and woof; and then it was woven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:47
verses.text: Accordingly the soul must be prepared and variously exercised, if it would become in the highest degree good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:48
verses.text: For there is the scientific and the practical element in truth; and the latter flows from the speculative; and there is need of great practice, and exercise, and experience.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:49
verses.text: But in speculation, one element relates to one's neighbours and another to one's self.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:50
verses.text: Wherefore also training ought to be so moulded as to be adapted to both.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:51
verses.text: He, then, who has acquired a competent acquaintance with the subjects which embrace the principles which conduce to scientific knowledge (gnosis), may stop and remain for the future in quiet, directing his actions in l conformity with his theory.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:52
verses.text: But for the benefit of one's neighbours, in the case of those who have proclivities for writing, and those who set themselves to deliver the word, both is other culture beneficial, and the reading of the Scriptures of the Lord is necessary, in order to the demonstration of what is said, and especially if those who hear are accessions from Hellenic culture.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:53
verses.text: Such David describes the Church: "The queen stood on thy right hand, enveloped in a golden robe, variegated;" and with Hellenic and superabundant accomplishments, "clothed variegated with gold-fringed garments".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:54
verses.text: And the Truth says by the Lord, "For who had known Thy counsel, hadst Thou not given wisdom, and sent Thy Holy Spirit from the Highest; and so the ways of those on earth were corrected, and men learned Thy decrees, and were saved by wisdom?" For the Gnostic knows things ancient by the Scripture, and conjectures things future: he understands the involutions of words and the solutions of enigmas.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:55
verses.text: He knows beforehand signs and wonders, and the issues of seasons and periods, as we have said already.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:56
verses.text: Seest thou the fountain of instructions that takes its rise from wisdom? But to those who object, What use is there in knowing the causes of the manner of the sun's motion, for example, and the rest of the heavenly bodies, or in having studied the theorems of geometry or logic, and each of the other branches of study?—for these are of no service in the discharge of duties, and the Hellenic philosophy is human wisdom, for it is incapable of teaching the truth—the following remarks are to be made.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:57
verses.text: First, that they stumble in reference to the highest of things—namely, the mind's free choice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:58
verses.text: "For they," it is said, "who keep holy holy things, shall be made holy; and those who have been taught will find an answer".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:59
verses.text: For the Gnostic alone will do holily, in accordance with reason all that has to be done, as he hath learned through the Lord's teaching, received through men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:60
verses.text: Again, on the other hand, we may hear: "For in His hand, that is, in His power and wisdom, are both we and our words, and all wisdom and skill in works; for God loves nothing but the man that dwells with wisdom".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:61
verses.text: And again, they have not read what is said by Solomon; for, treating of the construction of the temple, he says expressly, "And it was Wisdom as artificer that framed it; and Thy providence, O Father, governs throughout".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:62
verses.text: And how irrational, to regard philosophy as inferior to architecture and shipbuilding! And the Lord fed the multitude of those that reclined on the grass opposite to Tiberias with the two fishes and the five barley loaves, indicating the preparatory training of the Greeks and Jews previous to the divine grain, which is the food cultivated by the law.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:63
verses.text: For barley is sooner ripe for the harvest than wheat; and the fishes signified the Hellenic philosophy that was produced and moved in the midst of the Gentile billow, given, as they were, for copious food to those lying on the ground, increasing no more, like the fragments of the  loaves, but having partaken of the Lord's blessing, and breathed into them the resurrection of Godhead through the power of the Word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:64
verses.text: But if you are curious, understand one of the fishes to mean the curriculum of study, and the other the philosophy which supervenes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:65
verses.text: The gatherings point out the word of the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:66
verses.text: "And the choir of mute fishes rushed to it,"  says the Tragic Muse somewhere.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:67
verses.text: "I must decrease," said the prophet John, and the Word of the Lord alone, in which the law terminates, "increase".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:68
verses.text: Understand now for me the mystery of the truth, granting pardon if I shrink from advancing further in the treatment of it, by announcing this alone: "All things were made by Him, and without Him was not even one thing".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:69
verses.text: Certainly He is called "the chief corner stone; in whom the whole building, fitly joined together, groweth into an holy temple of God," according to the divine apostle.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:70
verses.text: I pass over in silence at present the parable which says in the Gospel: "The kingdom of heaven is like a man who cast a net into the sea and out of the multitude of the fishes caught, makes a selection of the better ones".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:71
verses.text: And now the wisdom which we possess announces the four virtues in such a way as to show that the sources of them were communicated by the Hebrews to the Greeks.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:72
verses.text: This may be learned from the following: "And if one loves justice, its toils are virtues.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:73
verses.text: For temperance and prudence teach justice and fortitude; and than these there is nothing more useful in life to men".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 11:74
verses.text: Above all, this ought to be known, that by nature we are adapted for virtue; not so as to be possessed of it from our birth, but so as to be adapted for acquiring it.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:1
verses.text: Chapter 12—Human Nature Possesses an Adaptation for Perfection; The Gnostic Alone Attains It.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:2
verses.text: By which consideration is solved the question propounded to us by the heretics, Whether Adam was created perfect or imperfect? Well, if imperfect, how could the work of a perfect God—above all, that work being man—be imperfect? And if perfect, how did he transgress the commandments? For they shall hear from us that he was not perfect in his creation, but adapted to the reception of virtue.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:3
verses.text: For it is of great importance in regard to virtue to be made fit for its attainment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:4
verses.text: And it is intended that we should be saved by ourselves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:5
verses.text: This, then, is the nature of the soul, to move of itself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:6
verses.text: Then, as we are rational, and philosophy being rational, we have some affinity with it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:7
verses.text: Now an aptitude is a movement towards virtue, not virtue itself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:8
verses.text: All, then, as I said, are naturally constituted for the acquisition of virtue.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:9
verses.text: But one man applies less, one more, to learning and training.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:10
verses.text: Wherefore also some have been competent to attain to perfect virtue, and others have attained to a kind of it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:11
verses.text: And some, on the other hand, through negligence, although in other respects of good dispositions, have turned to the opposite.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:12
verses.text: Now much more is that knowledge which excels all branches of culture in greatness and in truth, most difficult to acquire, and is attained with much toil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:13
verses.text: "But, as seems, they know not the mysteries of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:14
verses.text: For God created man for immortality, and made him an image of His own nature;" according to which nature of Him who knows all, he who is a Gnostic, and righteous, and holy with prudence, hastes to reach the measure of perfect manhood.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:15
verses.text: For not only are actions and thoughts, but words also, pure in the case of the Gnostic: "Thou hast proved mine heart; Thou hast visited me by night," it is said; "Thou hast subjected me to the fire, and unrighteousness was not found in me: so that my mouth shall not speak the works of men".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:16
verses.text: And why do I say the works of men? He recognises sin itself, which is not brought forward in order to repentance (for this is common to all believers); but what sin is.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:17
verses.text: Nor does he condemn this or that sin, but simply all sin; nor is it what one has done ill that he brings up, but what ought not to be done.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:18
verses.text: Whence also repentance is twofold: that which is common, on account of having transgressed; and that which, from learning the nature of sin, persuades, in the first instance, to keep from sinning, the result of which is not sinning.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:19
verses.text: Let them not then say, that he who does wrong and sins transgresses through the agency of demons; for then he would be guiltless.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:20
verses.text: But by choosing the same things as demons, by sinning; being unstable, and light, and fickle in his desires, like a demon, he becomes a demoniac man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:21
verses.text: Now he who is bad, having become, through evil, sinful by nature, becomes depraved, having what he has chosen; and being sinful, sins also in his actions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:22
verses.text: And again, the good man does right.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:23
verses.text: Wherefore we call not only the virtues, but also right actions, good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:24
verses.text: And of things that are  good we know that some are desirable for themselves, as knowledge; for we hunt for nothing from it when we have it, but only seek that it be with us, and that we be in uninterrupted contemplation, and strive to reach it for its own sake.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:25
verses.text: But other things are desirable for other considerations, such as faith, for escape from punishment, and the advantage arising from reward, which accrue from it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:26
verses.text: For, in the case of many, fear is the cause of their not sinning; and the promise is the means of pursuing obedience, by which comes salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:27
verses.text: Knowledge, then, desirable as it is for its own sake, is the most perfect good; and consequently the things which follow by means of it are good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:28
verses.text: And punishment is the cause of correction to him who is punished; and to those who are able to see before them he becomes an example, to prevent them falling into the like.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:29
verses.text: Let us then receive knowledge, not desiring its results, but embracing itself for the sake of knowing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:30
verses.text: For the first advantage is the habit of knowledge (γνωστική), which furnishes harmless pleasures and exultation both for the present and the future.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:31
verses.text: And exultation is said to be gladness, being a reflection of the virtue which is according to truth, through a kind of exhilaration and relaxation of soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:32
verses.text: And the acts which partake of knowledge are good and fair actions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:33
verses.text: For abundance in the actions that are according to virtue, is the true riches, and destitution in decorous desires is poverty.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:34
verses.text: For the use and enjoyment of necessaries are not injurious in quality, but in quantity, when in excess.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:35
verses.text: Wherefore the Gnostic circumscribes his desires in reference both to possession and to enjoyment, not exceeding the limit of necessity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:36
verses.text: Therefore, regarding life in this world as necessary for the increase of science (ἐπιστήμη) and the acquisition of knowledge (γνῶσις), he will value highest, not living, but living well.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:37
verses.text: He will therefore prefer neither children, nor marriage, nor parents, to love for God, and righteousness in life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:38
verses.text: To such an one, his wife, after conception, is as a sister, and is judged as if of the same father; then only recollecting her husband, when she looks on the children; as being destined to become a sister in reality after putting off the flesh, which separates and limits the knowledge of those who are spiritual by the peculiar characteristics of the sexes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:39
verses.text: For souls, themselves by themselves, are equal.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:40
verses.text: Souls are neither male nor female, when they no longer marry nor are given in marriage.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:41
verses.text: And is not woman translated into man, when she is become equally unfeminine, and manly, and perfect? Such, then, was the laughter of Sarah when she received the good news of the birth of a son; not, in my opinion, that she disbelieved the angel, but that she felt ashamed of the intercourse by means of which she was destined to become the mother of a son.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:42
verses.text: And did not Abraham, when he was in danger on account of Sarah's beauty, with the king of Egypt, properly call her sister, being of the same father, but not of the same mother?  To those, then, who have repented and not firmly believed, God grants their requests through their supplications.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:43
verses.text: But to those who live sinlessly and gnostically, He gives, when they have but merely entertained the thought.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:44
verses.text: For example, to Anna, on her merely conceiving the thought, conception was vouchsafed of the child Samuel.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:45
verses.text: "Ask," says the Scripture, "and I will do.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:46
verses.text: Think, and I will give".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:47
