verses.text: For we have heard that God knows the heart, not judging the soul from external movement, as we men; nor yet from the event.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:48
verses.text: For it is ridiculous to think so.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:49
verses.text: Nor was it as the architect praises the work when accomplished that God, on making the light and then seeing it, called it good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:50
verses.text: But He, knowing before He made it what it would be, praised that which was made, He having potentially made good, from the first by His purpose that had no beginning, what was destined to be good actually.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:51
verses.text: Now that which has future He already said beforehand was good, the phrase concealing the truth by hyperbaton.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:52
verses.text: Therefore the Gnostic prays in thought during every hour, being by love allied to God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:53
verses.text: And first he will ask forgiveness of sins; and after, that he may sin no more; and further, the power of well-doing and of comprehending the whole creation and administration by the Lord, that, becoming pure in heart through the knowledge, which is by the Son of God, he may be initiated into the beatific vision face to face, having heard the Scripture which says, "Fasting with prayer is a good thing".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:54
verses.text: Now fastings signify abstinence from all evils whatsoever, both in action and in word, and in thought itself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:55
verses.text: As appears, then, righteousness is quadrangular; on all sides equal and like in word, in deed, in abstinence from evils, in beneficence, in gnostic perfection; nowhere, and in no respect halting, so that he does not appear unjust and unequal.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:56
verses.text: As one, then, is righteous, so certainly is he a believer.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:57
verses.text: But as he is a believer, he is not yet also righteous—I mean according  to the righteousness of progress and perfection, according to which the Gnostic is called righteous.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:58
verses.text: For instance, on Abraham becoming a believer, it was reckoned to him for righteousness, he having advanced to the greater and more perfect degree of faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:59
verses.text: For he who merely abstains from evil conduct is not just, unless he also attain besides beneficence and knowledge; and for this reason some things are to be abstained from, others are to be done.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:60
verses.text: "By the armour of righteousness on the right hand and on the left," the apostle says, the righteous man is sent on to the inheritance above,—by some arms defended, by others putting forth his might.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:61
verses.text: For the defence of his panoply alone, and abstinence from sins, are not sufficient for perfection, unless he assume in addition the work of righteousness—activity in doing good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:62
verses.text: Then our dexterous man and Gnostic is revealed in righteousness already even here, as Moses, glorified in the face of the soul, as we have formerly said, the body bears the stamp of the righteous soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:63
verses.text: For as the mordant of the dyeing process, remaining in the wool, produces in it a certain quality and diversity from other wool; so also in the soul the pain is gone, but the good remains; and the sweet is left, but the base is wiped away.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:64
verses.text: For these are two qualities characteristic of each soul, by which is known that which is glorified, and that which is condemned.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:65
verses.text: And as in the case of Moses, from his righteous conduct, and from his uninterrupted intercourse with God, who spoke to him, a kind of glorified hue settled on his face; so also a divine power of goodness clinging to the righteous soul in contemplation and in prophecy, and in the exercise of the function of governing, impresses on it something, as it were, of intellectual radiance, like the solar ray, as a visible sign of righteousness, uniting the soul with light, through unbroken love, which is God-bearing and God-borne.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:66
verses.text: Thence assimilation to God the Saviour arises to the Gnostic, as far as permitted to human nature, he being made perfect "as the Father who is in heaven".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:67
verses.text: It is He Himself who says, "Little children, a little while I am still with you".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:68
verses.text: Since also God Himself remains blessed and immortal, neither molested nor molesting another; not in consequence of being by nature good, but in consequence of doing good in a manner peculiar to Himself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:69
verses.text: God being essentially, and proving Himself actually, both Father and good, continues immutably in the self-same goodness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 12:70
verses.text: For what is the use of good that does not act and do good?.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 13

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 13:1
verses.text: Chapter 13—Degrees of Glory in Heaven Corresponding with the Dignities of the Church Below.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 13:2
verses.text: He, then, who has first moderated his passions and trained himself for impassibility, and developed to the beneficence of gnostic perfection, is here equal to the angels.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 13:3
verses.text: Luminous already, and like the sun shining in the exercise of beneficence, he speeds by righteous knowledge through the love of God to the sacred abode, like as the apostles.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 13:4
verses.text: Not that they became apostles through being chosen for some distinguished peculiarity of nature, since also Judas was chosen along with them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 13:5
verses.text: But they were capable of becoming apostles on being chosen by Him who foresees even ultimate issues.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 13:6
verses.text: Matthias, accordingly, who was not chosen along with them, on showing himself worthy of becoming an apostle, is substituted for Judas.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 13:7
verses.text: Those, then, also now, who have exercised themselves in the Lord's commandments, and lived perfectly and gnostically according to the Gospel, may be enrolled in the chosen body of the apostles.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 13:8
verses.text: Such an one is in reality a presbyter of the Church, and a true minister (deacon) of the will of God, if he do and teach what is the Lord's; not as being ordained by men, nor regarded righteous because a presbyter, but enrolled in the presbyterate because righteous.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 13:9
verses.text: And although here upon earth he be not honoured with the chief seat, he will sit down on the four-and-twenty thrones, judging the people, as John says in the Apocalypse.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 13:10
verses.text: For, in truth, the covenant of salvation, reaching down to us from the foundation of the world, through different generations and times, is one, though conceived as different in respect of gift.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 13:11
verses.text: For it follows that there is one unchangeable gift of salvation given by one God, through one Lord, benefiting in many ways.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 13:12
verses.text: For which cause the middle wall which separated the Greek from the Jew is taken away, in order that there might be a peculiar people.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 13:13
verses.text: And so both meet in the one unity of faith; and the selection out of both is one.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 13:14
verses.text: And the chosen of the chosen are those who by reason of perfect knowledge are called as the best from the  Church itself, and honoured with the most august glory—the judges and rulers—four-and-twenty (the grace being doubled) equally from Jews and Greeks.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 13:15
verses.text: Since, according to my opinion, the grades here in the Church, of bishops, presbyters, deacons, are imitations of the angelic glory, and of that economy which, the Scriptures say, awaits those who, following the footsteps of the apostles, have lived in perfection of righteousness according to the Gospel.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 13:16
verses.text: For these taken up in the clouds, the apostle writes, will first minister as deacons, then be classed in the presbyterate, by promotion in glory (for glory differs from glory) till they grow into "a perfect man".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:1
verses.text: Chapter 14—Degrees of Glory in Heaven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:2
verses.text: Such, according to David, "rest in the holy hill of God," in the Church far on high, in which are gathered the philosophers of God, "who are Israelites indeed, who are pure in heart, in whom there is no guile;" who do not remain in the seventh seat, the place of rest, but are promoted, through the active beneficence of the divine likeness, to the heritage of beneficence which is the eighth grade; devoting themselves to the pure vision of insatiable contemplation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:3
verses.text: "And other sheep there are also," saith the Lord, "which are not of this fold"—deemed worthy of another fold and mansion, in proportion to their faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:4
verses.text: "But My sheep hear My voice," understanding gnostically the commandments.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:5
verses.text: And this is to be taken in a magnanimous and worthy acceptation, along with also the recompense and accompaniment of works.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:6
verses.text: So that when we hear, "Thy faith hath saved thee," we do not understand Him to say absolutely that those who have believed in any way whatever shall be saved, unless also works follow.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:7
verses.text: But it was to the Jews alone that He spoke this utterance, who kept the law and lived blamelessly, who wanted only faith in the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:8
verses.text: No one, then, can be a believer and at the same time be licentious; but though he quit the flesh, he must put off the passions, so as to be capable of reaching his own mansion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:9
verses.text: Now to know is more than to believe, as to be dignified with the highest honour after being saved is a greater thing than being saved.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:10
verses.text: Accordingly the believer, through great discipline, divesting himself of the passions, passes to the mansion which is better than the former one, viz.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:11
verses.text: , to the greatest torment, taking with him the characteristic of repentance from the sins he has committed after baptism.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:12
verses.text: He is tortured then still more—not yet or not quite attaining what he sees others to have acquired.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:13
verses.text: Besides, he is also ashamed of his transgressions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:14
verses.text: The greatest torments, indeed, are assigned to the believer.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:15
verses.text: For God's righteousness is good, and His goodness is righteous.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:16
verses.text: And though the punishments cease in the course of the completion of the expiation and purification of each one, yet those have very great and permanent grief who are found worthy of the other fold, on account of not being along with those that have been glorified through righteousness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:17
verses.text: For instance, Solomon, calling the Gnostic, wise, speaks thus of those who admire the dignity of his mansion: "For they shall see the end of the wise, and to what a degree the Lord has established him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:18
verses.text: And of his glory they will say, "This was he whom we once held up to derision, and made a byword of reproach; fools that we were! We thought his life madness, and his end dishonourable.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:19
verses.text: How is he reckoned among the sons of God, and his inheritance among the saints?"  Not only then the believer, but even the heathen, is judged most righteously.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:20
verses.text: For since God knew in virtue of His prescience that he would not believe, He nevertheless, in order that he might receive his own perfection gave him philosophy, but gave it him previous to faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:21
verses.text: And He gave the sun, and the moon, and the stars to be worshipped; "which God," the Law says, made for the nations, that they might not become altogether atheistical, and so utterly perish.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:22
verses.text: But they, also in the instance of this commandment, having become devoid of sense, and addicting themselves to graven images, are judged unless they repent; some of them because, though able, they would not believe God; and others because, though willing, they did not take the necessary pains to become believers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:23
verses.text: There were also, however, those who, from the worship of the heavenly bodies, did not return to the Maker of them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:24
verses.text: For this was the sway given to the nations to rise up to God, by means of the worship of the heavenly bodies.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:25
verses.text: But those who would not abide by those heavenly bodies assigned to them, but fell away from them to stocks and stones, "were counted," it is said, "as chaff-dust and as a drop from a jar," beyond salvation, cast away from the body.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:26
verses.text: As, then, to be simply saved is the result of  medium actions, but to be saved rightly and becomingly is right action, so also all action of the Gnostic may be called right action; that of the simple believer, intermediate action, not yet perfected according to reason, not yet made right according to knowledge; but that of every heathen again is sinful.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:27
verses.text: For it is not simply doing well, but doing actions with a certain aim, and acting according to reason, that the Scriptures exhibit as requisite.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:28
verses.text: As, then, lyres ought not to be touched by those who are destitute of skill in playing the lyre, nor flutes by those who are unskilled in flute-playing, neither are those to put their hand to affairs who have not knowledge, and know not how to use them in the whole of life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:29
verses.text: The struggle for freedom, then, is waged not alone by the athletes of battles in wars, but also in banquets, and in bed, and in the tribunals, by those who are anointed by the word, who are ashamed to become the captives of pleasures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:30
verses.text: "I would never part with virtue for unrighteous gain".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:31
verses.text: But plainly, unrighteous gain is pleasure and pain, toil and fear; and, to speak comprehensively, the passions of the soul, the present of which is delightful, the future vexatious.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:32
verses.text: "For what is the profit," it is said, "if you gain the world and lose the soul?" It is clear, then, that those who do not perform good actions, do not know what is for their own advantage.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:33
verses.text: And if so, neither are they capable of praying aright, so as to receive from God good things; nor, should they receive them, will they be sensible of the boon; nor, should they enjoy them, will they enjoy worthily what they know not; both from their want of knowledge how to use the good things given them, and from their excessive stupidity, being ignorant of the way to avail themselves of the divine gifts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:34
verses.text: Now stupidity is the cause of ignorance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:35
verses.text: And it appears to me that it is the vaunt of a boastful soul, though of one with a good conscience, to exclaim against what happens through circumstances:—  "Therefore let them do what they may; For it shall be well with me; and Right Shall be my ally, and I shall not be caught doing evil".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:36
verses.text: But such a good conscience preserves sanctity towards God and justice towards men; keeping the soul pure with grave thoughts, and pure words, and just deeds.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:37
verses.text: By thus receiving the Lord's power, the soul studies to be God; regarding nothing bad but ignorance, and action contrary to right reason.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:38
verses.text: And giving thanks always for all things to God, by righteous hearing and divine reading, by true investigation, by holy oblation, by blessed prayer; lauding, hymning, blessing, praising, such a soul is never at any time separated from God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:39
verses.text: Rightly then is it said, "And they who trust in Him shall understand the truth, and those faithful in love shall abide by Him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:40
verses.text: You see what statements Wisdom makes about the Gnostics.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:41
verses.text: Conformably, therefore, there are various abodes, according to the worth of those who have believed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:42
verses.text: To the point Solomon says, "For there shall be given to him the choice grace of faith, and a more pleasant lot in the temple of the Lord".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:43
verses.text: For the comparative shows that there are lower parts in the temple of God, which is the whole Church.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:44
verses.text: And the superlative remains to be conceived, where the Lord is.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:45
verses.text: These chosen abodes, which are three, are indicated by the numbers in the Gospel—the thirty, the sixty, the hundred.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:46
verses.text: And the perfect inheritance belongs to those who attain to "a perfect man," according to the image of the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:47
verses.text: And the likeness is not, as some imagine, that of the human form; for this consideration is impious.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:48
verses.text: Nor is the likeness to the first cause that which consists in virtue.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:49
verses.text: For this utterance is also impious, being that of those who have imagined that virtue in man and in the sovereign God is the same.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:50
verses.text: "Thou hast supposed iniquity," He says, "in imagining that I will be like to thee".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:51
verses.text: But "it is enough for the disciple to become as the Master," saith the Master.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 14:52
verses.text: To the likeness of God, then, he that is introduced into adoption and the friendship of God, to the just inheritance of the lords and gods is brought; if he be perfected, according to the Gospel, as the Lord Himself taught.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:1
verses.text: Chapter 15—Different Degrees of Knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:2
verses.text: The Gnostic, then, is impressed with the closest likeness, that is, with the mind of the Master; which He being possessed of, commanded and recommended to His disciples and to the prudent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:3
verses.text: Comprehending this, as He who taught wished, and receiving it in its grand sense, he teaches worthily "on the housetops" those capable of being built to a lofty height; and begins the doing of what is spoken, in accordance  with the example of life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:4
verses.text: For He enjoined what is possible.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:5
verses.text: And, in truth, the kingly man and Christian ought to be ruler and leader.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:6
verses.text: For we are commanded to be lords over not only the wild beasts without us, but also over the wild passions within ourselves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:7
verses.text: Through the knowledge, then, as appears, of a bad and good life is the Gnostic saved, understanding and executing "more than the scribes and Pharisees".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:8
verses.text: "Exert thyself, and prosper, and reign" writes David, "because of truth, and meekness, and righteousness; and thy right hand shall guide thee marvellously," that is, the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:9
verses.text: "Who then is the wise? and he shall understand these things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:10
verses.text: Prudent? and he shall know them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:11
verses.text: For the ways of the Lord are right," says the prophet, showing that the Gnostic alone is able to understand and explain the things spoken by the Spirit obscurely.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:12
verses.text: "And he who understands in that time shall hold his peace," says the Scripture, plainly in the way of declaring them to the unworthy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:13
verses.text: For the Lord says, "He that hath ears to hear, let him hear," declaring that hearing and understanding belong not to all.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:14
verses.text: To the point David writes: "Dark water is in the clouds of the skies.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:15
verses.text: At the gleam before Him the clouds passed, hail and coals of fire;" showing that the holy words are hidden.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:16
verses.text: He intimates that transparent and resplendent to the Gnostics, like the innocuous hail, they are sent down from God; but that they are dark to the multitude, like extinguished coals out of the fire, which, unless kindled and set on fire, will not give forth fire or light.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:17
verses.text: "The Lord, therefore," it is said, "gives me the tongue of instruction, so as to know in season when it is requisite to speak a word;" not in the way of testimony alone, but also in the way of question and answer.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:18
verses.text: "And the instruction of the Lord opens my mouth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:19
verses.text: It is the prerogative of the Gnostic, then, to know how to make use of speech, and when, and how, and to whom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:20
verses.text: And already the apostle, by saying, "After the rudiments of the world, and not after Christ," makes the asseveration that the Hellenic teaching is elementary, and that of Christ perfect, as we have already intimated before.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:21
verses.text: "Now the wild olive is inserted into the fatness of the olive," and is indeed of the same species as the cultivated olives.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:22
verses.text: For the graft uses as soil the tree in which it is engrafted.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:23
verses.text: Now all the plants sprouted forth simultaneously in consequence of the divine order.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:24
verses.text: Wherefore also, though the wild olive be wild, it crowns the Olympic victors.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:25
verses.text: And the elm teaches the vine to be fruitful, by leading it up to a height.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:26
verses.text: Now we see that wild trees attract more nutriment, because they cannot ripen.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:27
verses.text: The wild trees, therefore, have less power of secretion than those that are cultivated.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:28
verses.text: And the cause of their wildness is the want of the power of secretion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:29
verses.text: The engrafted olive accordingly receives more nutriment from its growing in the wild one; and it gets accustomed, as it were, to secrete the nutriment, becoming thus assimilated to the fatness of the cultivated tree.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:30
verses.text: So also the philosopher, resembling the wild olive, in having much that is undigested, on account of his devotion to the search, his propensity to follow, and his eagerness to seize the fatness of the truth; if he get besides the divine power, through faith, by being transplanted into the good and mild knowledge, like the wild olive, engrafted in the truly fair and merciful Word, he both assimilates the nutriment that is supplied, and becomes a fair and good olive tree.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:31
verses.text: For engrafting makes worthless shoots noble, and compels the barren to be fruitful by the art of culture and by gnostic skill.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:32
verses.text: Different modes of engrafting illustrative of different kinds of conversion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:33
verses.text: They say that engrafting is effected in four modes: one, that in which the graft must be fitted in between the wood and the bark; resembling the way in which we instruct plain people belonging to the Gentiles, who receive the word superficially.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:34
verses.text: Another is, when the wood is cleft, and there is inserted in it the cultivated branch.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:35
verses.text: And this applies to the case of those who have studied philosophy; for on cutting through their dogmas, the acknowledgment of the truth is produced in them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:36
verses.text: So also in the case of the Jews, by opening up the Old Testament, the new and noble plant of the olive is inserted.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:37
verses.text: The third mode of engrafting applies to rustics and heretics, who are brought by force to the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:38
verses.text: For after smoothing off both suckers with a sharp pruning-hook, till the pith is laid bare, but not wounded, they are bound together.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:39
verses.text: And the fourth is that form of engrafting called budding.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:40
verses.text: For a bud (eye) is cut out of a trunk of a good sort, a circle being drawn round in the bark along with it, of the size of the palm.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:41
verses.text: Then the trunk is stripped, to suit the eye, over an equal circumference.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:42
verses.text: And so the graft is inserted, tied round, and daubed with clay, the bud being kept uninjured and unstained.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:43
verses.text: This is the style of gnostic teaching, which is capable of looking into things themselves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:44
verses.text: This mode is, in truth, of most  service in the case of cultivated trees.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:45
verses.text: And "the engrafting into the good olive" mentioned by the apostle, may be engrafting into Christ Himself; the uncultivated and unbelieving nature being transplanted into Christ—that is, in the case of those who believe in Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:46
verses.text: But it is better to understand it of the engrafting of each one's faith in the soul itself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:47
verses.text: For also the Holy Spirit is thus somehow transplanted by distribution, according to the circumscribed capacity of each one, but without being circumscribed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:48
verses.text: Knowledge and love.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:49
verses.text: Now, discoursing on knowledge, Solomon speaks thus: "For wisdom is resplendent and fadeless, and is easily beheld by those who love her.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:50
verses.text: She is beforehand in making herself known to those who desire her.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:51
verses.text: He that rises early for her shall not toil wearily.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:52
verses.text: For to think about her is the perfection of good sense.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:53
verses.text: And he that keeps vigils for her shall quickly be relieved of anxiety.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:54
verses.text: For she goes about, herself seeking those worthy of her (for knowledge belongs not to all); and in all ways she benignly shows herself to them".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:55
verses.text: Now the paths are the conduct of life, and the variety that exists in the covenants.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:56
verses.text: Presently he adds: "And in every thought she meets them," being variously contemplated, that is, by all discipline.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:57
verses.text: Then he subjoins, adducing love, which perfects by syllogistic reasoning and true propositions, drawing thus a most convincing and true inference, "For the beginning of her is the truest desire of instruction," that is, of knowledge; "prudence is the love of instruction, and love is the keeping of its laws; and attention to its laws is the confirmation of immortality; and immortality causes nearness to God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:58
verses.text: The desire of wisdom leads, then, to the kingdom".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:59
verses.text: For he teaches, as I think, that true instruction is desire for knowledge; and the practical exercise of instruction produces love of knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:60
verses.text: And love is the keeping of the commandments which lead to knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:61
verses.text: And the keeping of them is the establishment of the commandments, from which immortality results.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:62
verses.text: "And immortality brings us near to God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:63
verses.text: True knowledge found in the teaching of Christ alone.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:64
verses.text: If, then, the love of knowledge produces immortality, and leads the kingly man near to God the King, knowledge ought to be sought till it is found.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:65
verses.text: Now seeking is an effort at grasping, and finds the subject by means of certain signs.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:66
verses.text: And discovery is the end and cessation of inquiry, which has now its object in its gasp.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:67
verses.text: And this is knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:68
verses.text: And this discovery, properly so called, is knowledge, which is the apprehension of the object of search.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:69
verses.text: And they say that a proof is either the antecedent, or the coincident, or the consequent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:70
verses.text: The discovery, then, of what is sought respecting God, is the teaching through the Son; and the proof of our Saviour being the very Son of God is the prophecies which preceded His coming, announcing Him; and the testimonies regarding Him which attended His birth in the world; in addition, His powers proclaimed and openly shown after His ascension.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:71
verses.text: The proof of the truth being with us, is the fact of the Son of God Himself having taught us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:72
verses.text: For if in every inquiry these universals are found, a person and a subject, that which is truly the truth is shown to be in our hands alone.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:73
verses.text: For the Son of God is the person of the truth which is exhibited; and the subject is the power of faith, which prevails over the opposition of every one whatever, and the assault of the whole world.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:74
verses.text: But since this is confessedly established by eternal facts and reasons, and each one who thinks that there is no Providence has already been seen to deserve punishment and not contradiction, and is truly an atheist, it is our aim to discover what doing, and in what manner living, we shall reach the knowledge of the sovereign God, and how, honouring the Divinity, we may become authors of our own salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:75
verses.text: Knowing and learning, not from the Sophists, but from God Himself, what is well-pleasing to Him, we endeavour to do what is just and holy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:76
verses.text: Now it is well-pleasing to Him that we should be saved; and salvation is effected through both well-doing and knowledge, of both of which the Lord is the teacher.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:77
verses.text: If, then, according to Plato, it is only possible to learn the truth either from God or from the progeny of God, with reason we, selecting testimonies from the divine oracles, boast of learning the truth by the Son of God, prophesied at first, and then explained.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:78
verses.text: Philosophy and heresies, aids in discovering the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:79
verses.text: But the things which co-operate in the discovery of truth are not to be rejected.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:80
verses.text: Philosophy, accordingly, which proclaims a Providence, and the recompense of a life of felicity, and the punishment, on the other hand, of a life of misery, teaches theology comprehensively; but it does not preserve accuracy and particular points; for neither respecting the Son of God, nor respecting the economy of Providence, does it treat similarly with us; for it did not know the worship of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:81
verses.text: Wherefore also the heresies of the Barbarian philosophy, although they speak of one God, though they sing the praises of Christ, speak without accuracy, not in accordance with truth; for they discover another God, and receive Christ not as the prophecies deliver.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:82
verses.text: But their false dogmas, while they oppose the conduct that is according to the truth, are against us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:83
verses.text: For instance, Paul circumcised Timothy because of the Jews who believed, in order that those who had received their training from the law might not revolt from the faith through his breaking such points of the law as were understood more carnally, knowing right well that circumcision does not justify; for he professed that "all things were for all" by conformity, preserving those of the dogmas that were essential, "that he might gain all".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:84
verses.text: And Daniel, under the king of the Persians, wore "the chain," though he despised not the afflictions of the people.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:85
verses.text: The liars, then, in reality are not those who for the sake of the scheme of salvation conform, nor those who err in minute points, but those who are wrong in essentials, and reject the Lord, and as far as in them lies deprive the Lord of the true teaching; who do not quote or deliver the Scriptures in a manner worthy of God and of the Lord; for the deposit rendered to God, according to the teaching of the Lord by His apostles, is the understanding and the practice of the godly tradition.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:86
verses.text: "And what ye hear in the ear"—that is, in a hidden manner, and in a mystery (for such things are figuratively said to be spoken in the ear)—"proclaim," He says, "on the housetops," understanding them sublimely, and delivering them in a lofty strain, and according to the canon of the truth explaining the Scriptures; for neither prophecy nor the Saviour Himself announced the divine mysteries simply so as to be easily apprehended by all and sundry, but express them in parables.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:87
verses.text: The apostles accordingly say of the Lord, that "He spake all things in parables, and without a parable spake He nothing unto them;" and if "all things were made by Him, and without Him was not anything made that was made," consequently also prophecy and the law were by Him, and were spoken by Him in parables.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:88
verses.text: "But all things are right," says the Scripture, "before those who understand," that is, those who receive and observe, according to the ecclesiastical rule, the exposition of the Scriptures explained by Him; and the ecclesiastical rule is the concord and harmony of the law and the prophets in the covenant delivered at the coming of the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:89
verses.text: Knowledge is then followed by practical wisdom, and practical wisdom by self-control: for it may be said that practical wisdom is divine knowledge, and exists in those who are deified; but that self-control is mortal, and subsists in those who philosophize, and are not yet wise.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:90
verses.text: But if virtue is divine, so is also the knowledge of it; while self-control is a sort of imperfect wisdom which aspires after wisdom, and exerts itself laboriously, and is not contemplative.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:91
verses.text: As certainly righteousness, being human, is, as being a common thing, subordinate to holiness, which subsists through the divine righteousness; for the righteousness of the perfect man does not rest on civil contracts, or on the prohibition of law, but flows from his own spontaneous action and his love to God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:92
verses.text: Reasons for the meaning of Scripture being veiled.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:93
verses.text: For many reasons, then, the Scriptures hide the sense.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:94
verses.text: First, that we may become inquisitive, and be ever on the watch for the discovery of the words of salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:95
verses.text: Then it was not suitable for all to understand, so that they might not receive harm in consequence of taking in another sense the things declared for salvation by the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:96
verses.text: Wherefore the holy mysteries of the prophecies are veiled in the parables—preserved for chosen men, selected to knowledge in consequence of their faith; for the style of the Scriptures is parabolic.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:97
verses.text: Wherefore also the Lord, who was not of the world, came as one who was of the world to men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:98
verses.text: For He was clothed with all virtue; and it was His aim to lead man, the foster-child of the world, up to the objects of intellect, and to the most essential truths by knowledge, from one world to another.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:99
verses.text: Wherefore also He employed metaphorical description; for such is the parable,—a narration based on some subject which is not the principal subject, but similar to the principal subject, and leading him who understands to what is the true and principal thing; or, as some say, a mode of speech presenting with vigour, by means of other circumstances, what is the principal subject.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:100
verses.text: And now also the whole economy which prophesied of the Lord appears indeed a parable to those who know not the truth, when one speaks and the rest hear that the Son of God—of Him who made the universe—assumed flesh, and was conceived in the virgin's womb (as His material body was produced), and subsequently,  as was the case, suffered and rose again, being "to the Jews a stumbling-block, and to the Greeks foolishness," as the apostle says.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:101
verses.text: But on the Scriptures being opened up, and declaring the truth to those who have ears, they proclaim the very suffering endured by the flesh, which the Lord assumed, to be "the power and wisdom of God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:102
verses.text: And finally, the parabolic style of Scripture being of the greatest antiquity, as we have shown, abounded most, as was to be expected, in the prophets, in order that the Holy Spirit might show that the philosophers among the Greeks, and the wise men among the Barbarians besides, were ignorant of the future coming of the Lord, and of the mystic teaching that was to be delivered by Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:103
verses.text: Rightly then, prophecy, in proclaiming the Lord, in order not to seem to some to blaspheme while speaking what was beyond the ideas of the multitude, embodied its declarations in expressions capable of leading to other conceptions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:104
verses.text: Now all the prophets who foretold the Lord's coming, and the holy mysteries accompanying it, were persecuted and killed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:105
verses.text: As also the Lord Himself, in explaining the Scriptures to them, and His disciples who preached the word like Him, and subsequently to His life, used parables.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:106
verses.text: Whence also Peter, in his Preaching, speaking of the apostles, says: "But we, unrolling the books of the prophets which we possess, who name Jesus Christ, partly in parables, partly in enigmas, partly expressly and in so many words, find His coming and death, and cross, and all the rest of the tortures which the Jews inflicted on Him, and His resurrection and assumption to heaven previous to the capture of Jerusalem.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:107
verses.text: As it is written, These things are all that He behoves to suffer, and what should be after Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:108
verses.text: Recognising them, therefore, we have believed in God in consequence of what is written respecting Him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:109
verses.text: And after a little again he draws the inference that the Scriptures owed their origin to the divine providence, asserting as follows: "For we know that God enjoined these things, and we say nothing apart from the Scriptures".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:110
verses.text: Now the Hebrew dialect, like all the rest, has certain properties, consisting in a mode of speech which exhibits the national character.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:111
verses.text: Dialect is accordingly defined as a style of speech produced by the national character.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:112
verses.text: But prophecy is not marked by those dialects.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:113
verses.text: For in the Hellenic writings, what are called changes of figures purposely produce onscurations, deduced after the style of our prophecies.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:114
verses.text: But this is effected through the voluntary departure from direct speech which takes place in metrical or offhand diction.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:115
verses.text: A figure, then, is a form of speech transferred from what is literal to what is not literal, for the sake of the composition, and on account of a diction useful in speech.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:116
verses.text: But prophecy does not employ figurative forms in the expressions for the sake of beauty of diction.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:117
verses.text: But from the fact that truth appertains not to all, it is veiled in manifold ways, causing the light to arise only on those who are initiated into knowledge, who seek the truth through love.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:118
verses.text: The proverb, according to the Barbarian philosophy, is called a mode of prophecy, and the parable is so called, and the enigma in addition.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:119
verses.text: Further also, they are called "wisdom;" and again, as something different from it, "instruction and words of prudence," and "turnings of words," and "true righteousness;" and again, "teaching to direct judgment," and "subtlety to the simple," which is the result of training, "and perception and thought," with which the young catechumen is imbued.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:120
verses.text: "He who hears these prophets, being wise, will be wiser.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:121
verses.text: And the intelligent man will acquire rule, and will understand a parable and a dark saying, the words and enigmas of the wise".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:122
verses.text: And if it was the case that the Hellenic dialects received their appellation from Hellen, the son of Zeus, surnamed Deucalion, from the chronology which we have already exhibited, it is comparatively easy to perceive by how many generations the dialects that obtained among the Greeks are posterior to the language of the Hebrews.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:123
verses.text: But as the work advances, we shall in each section, noting the figures of speech mentioned above by the prophet, exhibit the gnostic mode of life, showing it systematically according to the rule of the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:124
verses.text: Did not the Power also, that appeared to Hermas in the Vision, in the form of the Church, give for transcription the book which she wished to be made known to the elect? And this, he says, he transcribed to the letter, without finding how to complete the syllables.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:125
verses.text: And this signified that the Scripture is clear to all, when taken according to the bare reading; and that this is the faith which occupies the place of the rudiments.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:126
verses.text: Wherefore also the figurative expression is employed, "reading according to the letter;" while we understand that the gnostic unfolding of the Scriptures, when faith has already reached an advanced state, is likened to reading according to the syllables.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:127
verses.text: Further, Esaias the prophet is ordered to take "a new book, and write in it" certain things:  the Spirit prophesying that through the exposition of the Scriptures there would come afterwards the sacred knowledge, which at that period was still unwritten, because not yet known.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:128
verses.text: For it was spoken from the beginning to those only who understand.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:129
verses.text: Now that the Saviour has taught the apostles, the unwritten rendering of the written Scripture has been handed down also to us, inscribed by the power of God on hearts new, according to the renovation of the book.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:130
verses.text: Thus those of highest repute among the Greeks, dedicate the fruit of the pomegranate to Hermes, who they say is speech, on account of its interpretation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:131
verses.text: For speech conceals much.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:132
verses.text: Rightly, therefore, Jesus the son of Nave saw Moses, when taken up to heaven, double,—one Moses with the angels, and one on the mountains, honoured with burial in their ravines.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:133
verses.text: And Jesus saw this spectacle below, being elevated by the Spirit, along also with Caleb.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:134
verses.text: But both do not see similarly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:135
verses.text: But the one descended with greater speed, as if the weight he carried was great; while the other, on descending after him, subsequently related the glory which he beheld, being able to perceive more than the other as having grown purer; the narrative, in my opinion, showing that knowledge is not the privilege of all.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:136
verses.text: Since some look at the body of the Scriptures, the expressions and the names as to the body of Moses; while others see through to the thoughts and what it is signified by the names, seeking the Moses that is with the angels.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:137
verses.text: Many also of those who called to the Lord said, "Son of David, have mercy on me".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:138
verses.text: A few, too, knew Him as the Son of God; as Peter, whom also He pronounced blessed, "for flesh and blood revealed not the truth to him, but His Father in heaven,"—showing that the Gnostic recognises the Son of the Omnipotent, not by His flesh conceived in the womb, but by the Father's own power.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 15:139
verses.text: That it is therefore not only to those who read simply that the acquisition of the truth is so difficult, but that not even to those whose prerogative the knowledge of the truth is, is the contemplation of it vouch-safed all at once, the history of Moses teaches, until, accustomed to gaze, at the Hebrews on the glory of Moses, and the prophets of Israel on the visions of angels, so we also become able to look the splendours of truth in the face.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:1
verses.text: Chapter 16—Gnostic Exposition of the Decalogue.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:2
verses.text: Let the Decalogue be set forth cursorily by us as a specimen for gnostic exposition.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:3
verses.text: The number "Ten".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:4
verses.text: That ten is a sacred number, it is superfluous to say now.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:5
verses.text: And if the tables that were written were the work of God, they will be found to exhibit physical creation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:6
verses.text: For by the "finger of God" is understood the power of God, by which the creation of heaven and earth is accomplished; of both of which the tables will be understood to be symbols.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:7
verses.text: For the writing and handiwork of God put on the table is the creation of the world.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:8
verses.text: And the Decalogue, viewed as an image of heaven, embraces sun and moon, stars, clouds, light, wind, water, air, darkness, fire.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:9
verses.text: This is the physical Decalogue of the heaven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:10
verses.text: And the representation of the earth contains men, cattle, reptiles, wild beasts; and of the inhabitants of the water, fishes and whales; and again, of the winged tribes, those that are carnivorous, and those that use mild food; and of plants likewise, both fruit-bearing and barren.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:11
verses.text: This is the physical Decalogue of the earth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:12
verses.text: And the ark which held them will then be the knowledge of divine and human things and wisdom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:13
verses.text: And perhaps the two tables themselves may be the prophecy of the two covenants.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:14
verses.text: They were accordingly mystically renewed, as ignorance along with sin abounded.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:15
verses.text: The commandments are written, then, doubly, as appears, for twofold spirits, the ruling and the subject.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:16
verses.text: "For the flesh lusteth against the Spirit, and the Spirit against the flesh".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:17
verses.text: And there is a ten in man himself: the five senses, and the power of speech, and that of reproduction; and the eighth is the spiritual principle communicated at his creation; and the ninth the ruling faculty of the soul; and tenth, there is the distinctive characteristic of the Holy Spirit, which comes to him through faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:18
verses.text: Besides, in addition to these ten human parts, the law appear to give its injunctions to sight, and hearing, and smell, and touch, and taste, and to the organs subservient to these, which are double—the hands and the feet.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:19
verses.text: For such is the formation of man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:20
verses.text: And the soul is introduced, and previous to it the ruling faculty, by which we reason, not produced in procreation; so that without it there is made up the number ten, of the faculties by which all the activity of man is carried out.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:21
verses.text: For in order, straightway on man's entering existence, his life begins with sensations.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:22
verses.text: We accordingly assert that rational and ruling power is the cause of the constitution  of the living creature; also that this, the irrational part, is animated, and is a part of it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:23
verses.text: Now the vital force, in which is comprehended the power of nutrition and growth, and generally of motion, is assigned to the carnal spirit, which has great susceptibility of motion, and passes in all directions through the senses and the rest of the body, and through the body is the primary subject of sensations.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:24
verses.text: But the power of choice, in which investigation, and study, and knowledge, reside, belongs to the ruling faculty.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:25
verses.text: But all the faculties are placed in relation to one—the ruling faculty: it is through that man lives, and lives in a certain way.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:26
verses.text: Through the corporeal spirit, then, man perceives, desires, rejoices, is angry, is nourished, grows.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:27
verses.text: It is by it, too, that thoughts and conceptions advance to actions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:28
verses.text: And when it masters the desires, the ruling faculty reigns.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:29
verses.text: The commandment, then, "Thou shalt not lust," says, thou shalt not serve the carnal spirit, but shall rule over it; "For the flesh lusteth against the Spirit," and excites to disorderly conduct against nature; "and the Spirit against the flesh" exercises sway, in order that the conduct of the man may be according to nature.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:30
verses.text: Is not man, then, rightly said "to have been made in the image of God?"—not in the form of his corporeal structure; but inasmuch as God creates all things by the Word (λόγῳ), and the man who has become a Gnostic performs good actions by the faculty of reason (τῷ λογικῷ), properly therefore the two tables are also said to mean the commandments that were given to the twofold spirits,—those communicated before the law to that which was created, and to the ruling faculty; and the movements of the senses are both copied in the mind, and manifested in the activity which proceeds from the body.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:31
verses.text: For apprehension results from both combined.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:32
verses.text: Again, as sensation is related to the world of sense, so is thought to that of intellect.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:33
verses.text: And actions are twofold—those of thought, those of act.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:34
verses.text: The First Commandment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:35
verses.text: The first commandment of the Decalogue shows that there is one only Sovereign God; who led the people from the land of Egypt through the desert to their fatherland; that they might apprehend His power, as they were able, by means of the divine works, and withdraw from the idolatry of created things, putting all their hope in the true God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:36
verses.text: The Second Commandment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:37
verses.text: The second word intimated that men ought not to take and confer the august power of God (which is the name, for this alone were many even yet capable of learning), and transfer His title to things created and vain, which human artificers have made, among which "He that is" is not ranked.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:38
verses.text: For in His uncreated identity, "He that is" is absolutely alone.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:39
verses.text: The Fourth Commandment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:40
verses.text: And the fourth word is that which intimates that the world was created by God, and that He gave us the seventh day as a rest, on account of the trouble that there is in life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:41
verses.text: For God is incapable of weariness, and suffering, and want.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:42
verses.text: But we who bear flesh need rest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:43
verses.text: The seventh day, therefore, is proclaimed a rest—abstraction from ills—preparing for the Primal Day, our true rest; which, in truth, is the first creation of light, in which all things are viewed and possessed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:44
verses.text: From this day the first wisdom and knowledge illuminate us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:45
verses.text: For the light of truth—a light true, casting no shadow, is the Spirit of God indivisibly divided to all, who are sanctified by faith, holding the place of a luminary, in order to the knowledge of real existences.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:46
verses.text: By following Him, therefore, through our whole life, we become impassible; and this is to rest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:47
verses.text: Wherefore Solomon also says, that before heaven, and earth, and all existences, Wisdom had arisen in the Almighty; the participation of which—that which is by power, I mean, not that by essence—teaches a man to know by apprehension things divine and human.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:48
verses.text: Having reached this point, we must mention these things by the way; since the discourse has turned on the seventh and the eighth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:49
verses.text: For the eighth may possibly turn out to be properly the seventh, and the seventh manifestly the sixth, and the latter properly the Sabbath, and the seventh a day of work.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:50
verses.text: For the creation of the world was concluded in six days.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:51
verses.text: For the motion of the sun from solstice to solstice is completed in six months—in the course of which, at one time the leaves fall, and at another plants bud and seeds come to maturity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:52
verses.text: And they say that the embryo is perfected exactly in the sixth month, that is, in one hundred and eighty days in addition to the two and a half, as Polybus the physician relates in his book On the Eighth Month, and Aristotle the philosopher in his book On Nature.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:53
verses.text: Hence the Pythagoreans, as I think, reckon six the perfect number, from the creation of the world, according to the prophet, and call it Meseuthys  and Marriage, from its being the middle of the even numbers, that is, of ten and two.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:54
verses.text: For it is manifestly at an equal distance from both.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:55
verses.text: And as marriage generates from male and female, so six is generated from the odd number three, which is called the masculine number, and the even number two, which is considered the feminine.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:56
verses.text: For twice three are six.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:57
verses.text: Such, again, is the number of the most general motions, according to which all origination takes place—up, down, to the right, to the left, forward, backward.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:58
verses.text: Rightly, then, they reckon the number seven motherless and childless, interpreting the Sabbath, and figuratively expressing the nature of the rest, in which "they neither marry nor are given in marriage any more".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:59
verses.text: For neither by taking from one number and adding to another of those within ten is seven produced; nor when added to any number within the ten does it make up any of them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:60
verses.text: And they called eight a cube, counting the fixed sphere along with the seven revolving ones, by which is produced "the great year," as a kind of period of recompense of what has been promised.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:61
verses.text: Thus the Lord, who ascended the mountain, the fourth, becomes the sixth, and is illuminated all round with spiritual light, by laying bare the power proceeding from Him, as far as those selected to see were able to behold it, by the Seventh, the Voice, proclaimed to be the Son of God; in order that they, persuaded respecting Him, might have rest; while He by His birth, which was indicated by the sixth conspicuously marked, becoming the eighth, might appear to be God in a body of flesh, by displaying His power, being numbered indeed as a man, but being concealed as to who He was.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:62
verses.text: For six is reckoned in the order of numbers, but the succession of the letters acknowledges the character which is not written.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:63
verses.text: In this case, in the numbers themselves, each unit is preserved in its order up to seven and eight.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:64
verses.text: But in the number of the characters, Zeta becomes six and Eta seven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:65
verses.text: And the character having somehow slipped into writing, should we follow it out thus, the seven became six, and the eight seven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:66
verses.text: Wherefore also man is said to have been made on the sixth day, who became faithful to Him who is the sign (τῷ ἐπισήμῳ), so as straightway to receive the rest of the Lord's inheritance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:67
verses.text: Some such thing also is indicated by the sixth hour in the scheme of salvation, in which man was perfected.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:68
verses.text: Further, of the eight, the intermediates are seven; and of the seven, the intervals are shown to be six.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:69
verses.text: For that is another ground, in which seven glorifies eight, and "the heavens declare to the heavens the glory of God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:70
verses.text: The sensible types of these, then, are the sounds we pronounce.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:71
verses.text: Thus the Lord Himself is called "Alpha and Omega, the beginning and the end," "by whom all things were made, and without whom not even one thing was made".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:72
verses.text: God's resting is not, then, as some conceive, that God ceased from doing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:73
verses.text: For, being good, if He should ever cease from doing good, then would He cease from being God, which it is sacrilege even to say.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:74
verses.text: The resting is, therefore, the ordering that the order of created things should be preserved inviolate, and that each of the creatures should cease from the ancient disorder.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:75
verses.text: For the creations on the different days followed in a most important succession; so that all things brought into existence might have honour from priority, created together in thought, but not being of equal worth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:76
verses.text: Nor was the creation of each signified by the voice, inasmuch as the creative work is said to have made them at once.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:77
verses.text: For something must needs have been named first.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:78
verses.text: Wherefore those things were announced first, from which came those that were second, all things being originated together from one essence by one power.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:79
verses.text: For the will of God was one, in one identity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:80
verses.text: And how could creation take place in time, seeing time was born along with things which exist.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:81
verses.text: And now the whole world of creatures born alive, and things that grow, revolves in sevens.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:82
verses.text: The first-born princes of the angels, who have the greatest power, are seven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:83
verses.text: The mathematicians also say that the planets, which perform their course around the earth, are seven; by which the Chaldeans think that all which concerns mortal life is effected through sympathy, in consequence of which they also undertake to tell things respecting the future.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:84
verses.text: And of the fixed stars, the Pleiades are seven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:85
verses.text: And the Bears, by the help of which agriculture and navigation are carried through, consist of seven stars.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:86
verses.text: And in periods of seven days the moon undergoes its changes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:87
verses.text: In the first week she becomes half moon; in the second, full moon; and in the third, in her wane, again half moon; and in the fourth she disappears.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:88
verses.text: Further, as Seleucus the mathematician lays down, she has seven phases.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:89
verses.text: First, from being invisible she becomes crescent-shaped, then half  moon, then gibbous and full; and in her wane again gibbous, and in like manner half moon and crescent-shaped.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:90
verses.text: "On a seven-stringed lyre we shall sing new hymns,"  writes a poet of note, teaching us that the ancient lyre was seven-toned.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:91
verses.text: The organs of the senses situated on our face are also seven—two eyes, two passages of hearing, two nostrils, and the seventh the mouth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:92
verses.text: And that the changes in the periods of life take place by sevens, the Elegies of Solon teach thus:—  "The child, while still an infant, in seven years, Produces and puts forth its fence of teeth; And when God seven years more completes, He shows of puberty's approach the signs; And in the third, the beard on growing cheek With down o'erspreads the bloom of changing skin; And in the fourth septenniad, at his best In strength, of manliness he shows the signs; And in the fifth, of marriage, now mature, And of posterity, the man bethinks; Nor does he yet desire vain works to see.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:93
verses.text: The seventh and eighth septenniads see him now In mind and speech mature, till fifty years; And in the ninth he still has vigour left, But strength and body are for virtue great Less than of yore; when, seven years more, God brings To end, then not too soon may he submit to die".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:94
verses.text: Again, in diseases the seventh day is that of the crisis; and the fourteenth, in which nature struggles against the causes of the diseases.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:95
verses.text: And a myriad such instances are adduced by Hermippus of Berytus, in his book On the Number Seven, regarding it as holy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:96
verses.text: And the blessed David delivers clearly to those who know the mystic account of seven and eight, praising thus: "Our years were exercised like a spider.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:97
verses.text: The days of our years in them are seventy years; but if in strength, eighty years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:98
verses.text: And that will be to reign".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:99
verses.text: That, then, we may be taught that the world was originated, and not suppose that God made it in time, prophecy adds: "This is the book of the generation: also of the things in them, when they were created in the day that God made heaven and earth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:100
verses.text: For the expression "when they were created" intimates an indefinite and dateless production.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:101
verses.text: But the expression "in the day that God made," that is, in and by which God made "all things," and "without which not even one thing was made," points out the activity exerted by the Son.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:102
verses.text: As David says, "This is the day which the Lord hath made; let us be glad and rejoice in it;" that is, in consequence of the knowledge imparted by Him, let us celebrate the divine festival; for the Word that throws light on things hidden, and by whom each created thing came into life and being, is called day.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:103
verses.text: And, in fine, the Decalogue, by the letter Iota, signifies the blessed name, presenting Jesus, who is the Word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:104
verses.text: The Fifth Commandment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:105
verses.text: Now the fifth in order is the command on the honour of father and mother.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:106
verses.text: And it clearly announces God as Father and Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:107
verses.text: Wherefore also it calls those who know Him sons and gods.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:108
verses.text: The Creator of the universe is their Lord and Father; and the mother is not, as some say, the essence from which we sprang, nor, as others teach, the Church, but the divine knowledge and wisdom, as Solomon says, when he terms wisdom "the mother of the just," and says that it is desirable for its own sake.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:109
verses.text: And the knowledge of all, again, that is lovely and venerable, proceeds from God through the Son.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:110
verses.text: The Sixth Commandment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:111
