verses.text: Then follows the command about murder.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:112
verses.text: Now murder is a sure destruction.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:113
verses.text: He, then, that wishes to extirpate the true doctrine of God and of immortality, in order to introduce falsehood, alleging either that the universe is not under Providence, or that the world is uncreated, or affirming anything against true doctrine, is most pernicious.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:114
verses.text: The Seventh Commandment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:115
verses.text: This is followed by the command respecting adultery.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:116
verses.text: Now it is adultery, if one, abandoning the ecclesiastical and true knowledge, and the persuasion respecting God, accedes to false and incongruous opinion, either by deifying any created object, or by making an idol of anything that exists not, so as to overstep, or rather step from, knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:117
verses.text: And to the Gnostic false opinion is foreign, as the true belongs to him, and is allied with him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:118
verses.text: Wherefore the noble apostle calls one of the kinds of fornication, idolatry, in following the prophet, who says: "My people hath committed fornication with stock and stone.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:119
verses.text: They have said to the stock, Thou art my father; and to the stone, Thou hast begotten me".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:120
verses.text: The Eighth Commandment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:121
verses.text: And after this is the command respecting theft.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:122
verses.text: As, then, he that steals what is another's, doing great wrong, rightly incurs ills suitable to  his deserts; so also does he, who arrogates to himself divine works by the art of the statuary or the painter, and pronounces himself to be the maker of animals and plants.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:123
verses.text: Likewise those, too, who mimic the true philosophy are thieves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:124
verses.text: Whether one be a husbandman or the father of a child, he is an agent in depositing seeds.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:125
verses.text: But it is God who, ministering the growth and perfection of all things, brings the things produced to what is in accordance with their nature.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:126
verses.text: But the most, in common also with the philosophers, attribute growth and changes to the stars as the primary cause, robbing the Father of the universe, as far as in them lies, of His tireless might.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:127
verses.text: The elements, however, and the stars—that is, the administrative powers—are ordained for the accomplishment of what is essential to the administration, and are influenced and moved by what is commanded to them, in the way in which the Word of the Lord leads, since it is the nature of the divine power to work all things secretly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:128
verses.text: He, accordingly, who alleges that he has conceived or made anything which pertains to creation, will suffer the punishment of his impious audacity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:129
verses.text: The Tenth Commandment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:130
verses.text: And the tenth is the command respecting all lusts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:131
verses.text: As, then, he who entertains unbecoming desires is called to account; in the same way he is not allowed to desire things false, or to suppose that, of created objects, those that are animate have power of themselves, and that inanimate things can at all save or hurt.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:132
verses.text: And should one say that an antidote cannot heal or hemlock kill, he is unwittingly deceived.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:133
verses.text: For none of these operates except one makes use of the plant and the drug; just as the axe does not without one to cut with it, or a saw without one sawing with it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 16:134
verses.text: And as they do not work by themselves, but have certain physical qualities which accomplish their proper work by the exertion of the artisan; so also, by the universal providence of God, through the medium of secondary causes, the operative power is propagated in succession to individual objects.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:1
verses.text: Chapter 17—Philosophy Conveys Only an Imperfect Knowledge of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:2
verses.text: But, as appears, the philosophers of the Greeks, while naming God, do not know Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:3
verses.text: But their philosophical speculations, according to Empedocles, "as passing over the tongue of the multitude, are poured out of mouths that know little of the whole".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:4
verses.text: For as art changes the light of the sun into fire by passing it through a glass vessel full of water, so also philosophy, catching a spark from the divine Scripture, is visible in a few.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:5
verses.text: Also, as all animals breathe the same air, some in one way, others in another, and to a different purpose; so also a considerable number of people occupy themselves with the truth, or rather with discourse concerning the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:6
verses.text: For they do not say aught respecting God, but expound Him by attributing their own affections to God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:7
verses.text: For they spend life in seeking the probable, not the true.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:8
verses.text: But truth is not taught by imitation, but by instruction.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:9
verses.text: For it is not that we may seem good that we believe in Christ, as it is not alone for the purpose of being seen, while in the sun, that we pass into the sun.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:10
verses.text: But in the one case for the purpose of being warmed; and in the other, we are compelled to be Christians in order to be excellent and good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:11
verses.text: For the kingdom belongs pre-eminently to the violent, who, from investigation, and study, and discipline, reap this fruit, that they become kings.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:12
verses.text: He, then, who imitates opinion shows also preconception.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:13
verses.text: When then one, having got an inkling of the subject, kindles it within in his soul by desire and study, he sets everything in motion afterwards in order to know it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:14
verses.text: For that which one does not apprehend, neither does he desire it, nor does he embrace the advantage flowing from it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:15
verses.text: Subsequently, therefore, the Gnostic at last imitates the Lord, as far as allowed to men, having received a sort of quality akin to the Lord Himself, in order to assimilation to God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:16
verses.text: But those who are not proficient in knowledge cannot judge the truth by rule.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:17
verses.text: It is not therefore possible to share in the gnostic contemplations, unless we empty ourselves of our previous notions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:18
verses.text: For the truth in regard to every object of intellect and of sense is thus simply universally declared.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:19
verses.text: For instance, we may distinguish the truth of painting from that which is vulgar, and decorous music from licentious.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:20
verses.text: There is, then, also a truth of philosophy as distinct from the other philosophies, and a true beauty as distinct from the spurious.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:21
verses.text: It is not then the partial truths, of which truth is predicated, but the truth itself, that we are to investigate, not seeking to learn names.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:22
verses.text: For what is to be investigated respecting God is not one thing, but ten thousand.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:23
verses.text: There is a difference between declaring God, and declaring things about God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:24
verses.text: And to speak generally, in everything the accidents are to be distinguished from the essence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:25
verses.text: Suffice it for me to say, that the Lord of all is God; and I say the Lord of all absolutely, nothing being left by way of exception.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:26
verses.text: Since, then, the forms of truth are two—the names and the things—some discourse of names, occupying themselves with the beauties of words: such are the philosophers among the Greeks.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:27
verses.text: But we who are Barbarians have the things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:28
verses.text: Now it was not in vain that the Lord chose to make use of a mean form of body; so that no one praising the grace and admiring the beauty might turn his back on what was said, and attending to what ought to be abandoned, might be cut off from what is intellectual.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:29
verses.text: We must therefore occupy ourselves not with the expression, but the meaning.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:30
verses.text: To those, then, who are not gifted with the power of apprehension, and are not inclined to knowledge, the word is not entrusted; since also the ravens imitate human voices, having no understanding of the thing which they say.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:31
verses.text: And intellectual apprehension depends on faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:32
verses.text: Thus also Homer said:—  "Father of men and gods,"—  knowing not who the Father is, or how He is Father.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:33
verses.text: And as to him who has hands it is natural to grasp, and to him who has sound eyes to see the light; so it is the natural prerogative of him who has received faith to apprehend knowledge, if he desires, on "the foundation" laid, to work, and build up "gold, silver, precious stones".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:34
verses.text: Accordingly he does not profess to wish to participate, but begins to do so.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:35
verses.text: Nor does it belong to him to intend, but to be regal, and illuminated, and gnostic.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:36
verses.text: Nor does it appertain to him to wish to grasp things in name, but in fact.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:37
verses.text: For God, being good, on account of the principal part of the whole creation, seeing He wishes to save it, was induced to make the rest also; conferring on them at the beginning this first boon, that of existence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:38
verses.text: For that to be is far better than not to be, will be admitted by every one.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:39
verses.text: Then, according to the capabilities of their nature, each one was and is made, advancing to that which is better.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:40
verses.text: So there is no absurdity in philosophy having been given by Divine Providence as a preparatory discipline for the perfection which is by Christ; unless philosophy is ashamed at learning from Barbarian knowledge how to advance to truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:41
verses.text: But if "the very hairs are numbered, and the most insignificant motions," how shall not philosophy be taken into account? For to Samson power was given in his hair, in order that he might perceive that the worthless arts that refer to the things in this life, which lie and remain on the ground after the departure of the soul, were not given without divine power.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:42
verses.text: But it is said Providence, from above, from what is of prime importance, as from the head, reaches to all, "as the ointment," it is said, "which descends to Aaron's beard, and to the skirt of his garment" (that is, of the great High Priest, "by whom all things were made, and without whom not even one thing was made"); not to the ornament of the body; for Philosophy is outside of the People, like raiment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:43
verses.text: The philosophers, therefore, who, trained to their own peculiar power of perception by the spirit of perception, when they investigate, not a part of philosophy, but philosophy absolutely, testify to the truth in a truth-loving and humble spirit; if in the case of good things said by those even who are of different sentiments they advance to understanding, through the divine administration, and the ineffable Goodness, which always, as far as possible, leads the nature of existences to that which is better.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:44
verses.text: Then, by cultivating the acquaintance not of Greeks alone, but also of Barbarians, from the exercise common to their proper intelligence, they are conducted to Faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:45
verses.text: And when they have embraced the foundation of truth, they receive in addition the power of advancing further to investigation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:46
verses.text: And thence they love to be learners, and aspiring after knowledge, haste to salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:47
verses.text: Thus Scripture says, that "the spirit of perception" was given to the artificers from God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:48
verses.text: And this is nothing else than Understanding, a faculty of the soul, capable of studying existences,—of distinguishing and comparing what succeeds as like and unlike,—of enjoining and forbidding, and of conjecturing the future.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:49
verses.text: And it extends not to the arts alone, but even to philosophy itself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:50
verses.text: Why, then, is the serpent called wise? Because even in its wiles there may be found a connection, and distinction, and combination, and conjecturing of the future.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:51
verses.text: And so very many crimes are concealed; because the wicked arrange for themselves so as by all means to escape punishment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:52
verses.text: And Wisdom being manifold, pervading the whole world, and all human affairs, varies its appellation in each case.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:53
verses.text: When it applies itself to first causes, it is called Understanding (νόησις).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:54
verses.text: When, however, it confirms this by demonstrative reasoning, it is termed Knowledge, and Wisdom, and Science.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:55
verses.text: When it is occupied in what pertains to piety, and receives without speculation the primal Word in consequence of the maintenance of the operation in it, it is called Faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:56
verses.text: In the sphere of things of sense, establishing that which appears as being truest, it is  Right Opinion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:57
verses.text: In operations, again, performed by skill of hand, it is Art.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:58
verses.text: But when, on the other hand, without the study of primary causes, by the observation of similarities, and by transposition, it makes any attempt or combination, it is called Experiment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:59
verses.text: But belonging to it, and supreme and essential, is the Holy Spirit, which above all he who, in consequence of divine guidance, has believed, receives after strong faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:60
verses.text: Philosophy, then, partaking of a more exquisite perception, as has been shown from the above statements, participates in Wisdom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:61
verses.text: Logical discussion, then, of intellectual subjects, with selection and assent, is called Dialectics; which establishes, by demonstration, allegations respecting truth, and demolishes the doubts brought forward.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:62
verses.text: Those, then, who assert that philosophy did not come hither from God, all but say that God does not know each particular thing, and that He is not the cause of all good things; if, indeed, each of these belongs to the class of individual things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:63
verses.text: But nothing that exists could have subsisted at all, had God not willed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:64
verses.text: And if He willed, then philosophy is from God, He having willed it to be such as it is, for the sake of those who not otherwise than by its means would abstain from what is evil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:65
verses.text: For God knows all things—not those only which exist, but those also which shall be—and how each thing shall be.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:66
verses.text: And foreseeing the particular movements, "He surveys all things, and hears all things," seeing the soul naked within; and possesses from eternity the idea of each thing individually.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:67
verses.text: And what applies to theatres, and to the parts of each object, in looking at, looking round, and taking in the whole in one view, applies also to God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:68
verses.text: For in one glance He views all things together, and each thing by itself; but not all things, by way of primary intent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:69
verses.text: Now, then, many things in life take their rise in some exercise of human reason, having received the kindling spark from God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:70
verses.text: For instance, health by medicine, and soundness of body through gymnastics, and wealth by trade, have their origin and existence in consequence of Divine Providence indeed, but in consequence, too, of human co-operation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:71
verses.text: Understanding also is from God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:72
verses.text: But God's will is especially obeyed by the free-will of good men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:73
verses.text: Since many advantages are common to good and bad men: yet they are nevertheless advantageous only to men of goodness and probity, for whose sake God created them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:74
verses.text: For it was for the use of good men that the influence which is in God's gifts was originated.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:75
verses.text: Besides, the thoughts of virtuous men are produced through the inspiration of God; the soul being disposed in the way it is, and the divine will being conveyed to human souls, particular divine ministers contributing to such services.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:76
verses.text: For regiments of angels are distributed over the nations and cities.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:77
verses.text: And, perchance, some are assigned to individuals.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:78
verses.text: The Shepherd, then, cares for each of his sheep; and his closest inspection is given to those who are excellent in their natures, and are capable of being most useful.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:79
verses.text: Such are those fit to lead and teach, in whom the action of Providence is conspicuously seen; whenever either by instruction, or government, or administration, God wishes to benefit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:80
verses.text: But He wishes at all times.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:81
verses.text: Wherefore He moves those who are adapted to useful exertion in the things which pertain to virtue, and peace, and beneficence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:82
verses.text: But all that is characterized by virtue proceeds from virtue, and leads back to virtue.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:83
verses.text: And it is given either in order that men may become good, or that those who are so may make use of their natural advantages.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:84
verses.text: For it co-operates both in what is general and what is particular.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:85
verses.text: How absurd, then, is it, to those who attribute disorder and wickedness to the devil, to make him the bestower of philosophy, a virtuous thing! For he is thus all but made more benignant to the Greeks, in respect of making men good, than the divine providence and mind.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:86
verses.text: Again, I reckon it is the part of law and of right reason to assign to each one what is appropriate to him, and belongs to him, and falls to him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:87
verses.text: For as the lyre is only for the harper, and the flute for the flute-player; so good things are the possessions of good men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:88
verses.text: As the nature of the beneficent is to do good, as it is of the fire to warm, and the light to give light, and a good man will not do evil, or light produce darkness, or fire cold; so, again, vice cannot do aught virtuous.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:89
verses.text: For its activity is to do evil, as that of darkness to dim the eyes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:90
verses.text: Philosophy is not, then, the product of vice, since it makes men virtuous; it follows, then, that it is the work of God, whose work it is solely to do good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:91
verses.text: And all things given by God are given and received well.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:92
verses.text: Further, if the practice of philosophy does not belong to the wicked, but was accorded to the best of the Greeks, it is clear also from what source it was bestowed—manifestly from Providence, which assigns to each what is befitting in accordance with his deserts".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:93
verses.text: Rightly, then, to the Jews belonged the Law,  and to the Greeks Philosophy, until the Advent; and after that came the universal calling to be a peculiar people of righteousness, through the teaching which flows from faith, brought together by one Lord, the only God of both Greeks and Barbarians, or rather of the whole race of men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:94
verses.text: We have often called by the name philosophy that portion of truth attained through philosophy, although but partial.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:95
verses.text: Now, too what is good in the arts as arts, have their beginning from God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:96
verses.text: For as the doing of anything artistically is embraced in the rules of art, so also acting sagaciously is classed under the head of sagacity (φρόνησις).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:97
verses.text: Now sagacity is virtue, and it is its function to know other things, but much more especially what belongs to itself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:98
verses.text: And Wisdom (Σοφία) being power, is nothing but the knowledge of good things, divine and human.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:99
verses.text: But "the earth is God's, and the fulness thereof," says the Scripture, teaching that good things come from God to men; it being through divine power and might that the distribution of them comes to the help of man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:100
verses.text: Now the modes of all help and communication from one to another are three.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:101
verses.text: One is, by attending to another, as the master of gymnastics, in training the boy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:102
verses.text: The second is, by assimilation, as in the case of one who exhorts another to benevolence by practising it before.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:103
verses.text: The one co-operates with the learner, and the other benefits him who receives.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:104
verses.text: The third mode is that by command, when the gymnastic master, no longer training the learner, nor showing in his own person the exercise for the boy to imitate, prescribes the exercise by name to him, as already proficient in it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:105
verses.text: The Gnostic, accordingly, having received from God the power to be of service, benefits some by disciplining them, by bestowing attention on them; others, by exhorting them, by assimilation; and others, by training and teaching them, by command.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:106
verses.text: And certainly he himself is equally benefited by the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:107
verses.text: Thus, then, the benefit that comes from God to men becomes known—angels at the same time lending encouragement.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:108
verses.text: For by angels, whether seen or not, the divine power bestows good things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:109
verses.text: Such was the mode adopted in the advent of the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:110
verses.text: And sometimes also the power "breathes" in men's thoughts and reasonings, and "puts in" their hearts "strength" and a keener perception, and furnishes "prowess" and "boldness of alacrity" both for researches and deeds.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:111
verses.text: But exposed for imitation and assimilation are truly admirable and holy examples of virtue in the actions put on record.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:112
verses.text: Further, the department of action is most conspicuous both in the testaments of the Lord, and in the laws in force among the Greeks, and also in the precepts of philosophy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:113
verses.text: And to speak comprehensively, all benefit appertaining to life, in its highest reason, proceeding from the Sovereign God, the Father who is over all, is consummated by the Son, who also on this account "is the Saviour of all men," says the apostle, "but especially of those who believe".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 17:114
verses.text: But in respect of its immediate reason, it is from those next to each, in accordance with the command and injunction of Him who is nearest the First Cause, that is, the Lord.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:1
verses.text: Chapter 18—The Use of Philosophy to the Gnostic.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:2
verses.text: Greek philosophy the recreation of the Gnostic.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:3
verses.text: Now our Gnostic always occupies himself with the things of highest importance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:4
verses.text: But if at any time he has leisure and time for relaxation from what is of prime consequence, he applies himself to Hellenic philosophy in preference to other recreation, feasting on it as a kind of dessert at supper.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:5
verses.text: Not that he neglects what is superior; but that he takes this in addition, as long as proper, for the reasons I mentioned above.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:6
verses.text: But those who give their mind to the unnecessary and superfluous points of philosophy, and addict themselves to wrangling sophisms alone, abandon what is necessary and most essential, pursuing plainly the shadows of words.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:7
verses.text: It is well indeed to know all.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:8
verses.text: But the man whose soul is destitute of the ability to reach to acquaintance with many subjects of study, will select the principal and better subjects alone.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:9
verses.text: For real science (ἐπιστήμη, which we affirm the Gnostic alone possesses) is a sure comprehension (κατάληψις), leading up through true and sure reasons to the knowledge (γνῶσις) of the cause.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:10
verses.text: And he, who is acquainted with what is true respecting any one subject, becomes of course acquainted with what is false respecting it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:11
verses.text: Philosophy necessary.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:12
verses.text: For truly it appears to me to be a proper point for discussion, Whether we ought to philosophize: for its terms are consistent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:13
verses.text: But if we are not to philosophize, what then? (For no one can condemn a thing without first knowing it): the consequence, even in that case, is that we must philosophize.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:14
verses.text: First of all, idols are to be rejected.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:15
verses.text: Such, then, being the case, the Greeks ought by the Law and the Prophets to learn to worship one God only, the only Sovereign; then to be taught by the apostle, "but to us an idol is nothing in the world," since nothing among created things can be a likeness of God; and further, to be taught that none of those images which they worship can be similitudes: for the race of souls is not in form such as the Greeks fashion their idols.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:16
verses.text: For souls are invisible; not only those that are rational, but those also of the other animals.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:17
verses.text: And their bodies never become parts of the souls themselves, but organs—partly as seats, partly as vehicles—and in other cases possessions in various ways.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:18
verses.text: But it is not possible to copy accurately even the likenesses of the organs; since, were it so, one might model the sun, as it is seen, and take the likeness of the rainbow in colours.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:19
verses.text: After abandoning idols, then, they will hear the Scripture, "Unless your righteousness exceed the righteousness of the scribes and Pharisees" (who justified themselves in the way of abstinence from what was evil),—so as, along with such perfection as they evinced, and "the loving of your neighbour," to be able also to do good, you shall not "be kingly".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:20
verses.text: For intensification of the righteousness which is according to the law shows the Gnostic.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:21
verses.text: So one who is placed in the head, which is that which rules its own body—and who advances to the summit of faith, which is the knowledge (gnosis) itself, for which all the organs of perception exist—will likewise obtain the highest inheritance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:22
verses.text: The primacy of knowledge the apostle shows to those capable of reflection, in writing to those Greeks of Corinth, in the following terms: "But having hope, when your faith is increased, that we shall be magnified in you according to our rule abundantly, to preach the Gospel beyond you".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:23
verses.text: He does not mean the extension of his preaching locally: for he says also that in Achaia faith abounded; and it is related also in the Acts of the Apostles that he preached the word in Athens.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:24
verses.text: But he teaches that knowledge (gnosis), which is the perfection of faith, goes beyond catechetical instruction, in accordance with the magnitude of the Lord's teaching and the rule of the Church.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:25
verses.text: Wherefore also he proceeds to add, "And if I am rude in speech, yet I am not in knowledge".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:26
verses.text: Whence is the knowledge of truth?  But let those who vaunt on account of having apprehended the truth tell us from whom they boast of having heard it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:27
verses.text: They will not say from God, but will admit that it was from men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:28
verses.text: And if so, it is either from themselves that they have learned it lately, as some of them arrogantly boast, or from others like them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:29
verses.text: But human teachers, speaking of God, are not reliable, as men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:30
verses.text: For he that is man cannot speak worthily the truth concerning God: the feeble and mortal cannot speak worthily of the Unoriginated and Incorruptible—the work, of the Workman.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:31
verses.text: Then he who is incapable of speaking what is true respecting himself, is he not much less reliable in what concerns God? For just as far as man is inferior to God in power, so much feebler is man's speech than Him; although he do not declare God, but only speak about God and the divine word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:32
verses.text: For human speech is by nature feeble, and incapable of uttering God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:33
verses.text: I do not say His name.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:34
verses.text: For to name it is common, not to philosophers only, but also to poets.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:35
verses.text: Nor do I say His essence; for this is impossible, but the power and the works of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:36
verses.text: Those even who claim God as their teacher, with difficulty attain to a conception of God, grace aiding them to the attainment of their modicum of knowledge; accustomed as they are to contemplate the will of God by the will, and the Holy Spirit by the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:37
verses.text: "For the Spirit searches the deep things of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:38
verses.text: But the natural man receiveth not the things of the Spirit".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:39
verses.text: The only wisdom, therefore, is the God-taught wisdom we possess; on which depend all the sources of wisdom, which make conjectures at the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:40
verses.text: Intimations of the Teacher's advent  Assuredly of the coming of the Lord, who has taught us, to men, there were a myriad indicators, heralds, preparers, precursors, from the beginning, from the foundation of the world, intimating beforehand by deeds and words, prophesying that He would come, and where, and how, what should be the signs.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:41
verses.text: From afar certainly Law and Prophecy kept Him in view beforehand.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:42
verses.text: And then the precursor pointed Him out as present.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:43
verses.text: After whom the heralds point out by their teaching the virtue of His manifestation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:44
verses.text: Universal diffusion of the Gospel a contrast to philosophy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:45
verses.text: The philosophers, however, chose to teach philosophy to the Greeks alone, and not even to all of them; but Socrates to Plato, and Plato  to Xenocrates, Aristotle to Theophrastus, and Zeno to Cleanthes, who persuaded their own followers alone.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:46
verses.text: But the word of our Teacher remained not in Judea alone, as philosophy did in Greece; but was diffused over the whole world, over every nation, and village, and town, bringing already over to the truth whole houses, and each individual of those who heard it by him himself, and not a few of the philosophers themselves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:47
verses.text: And if any one ruler whatever prohibit the Greek philosophy, it vanishes forthwith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:48
verses.text: But our doctrine on its very first proclamation was prohibited by kings and tyrants together, as well as particular rulers and governors, with all their mercenaries, and in addition by innumerable men, warring against us, and endeavouring as far as they could to exterminate it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:49
verses.text: But it flourishes the more.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:50
verses.text: For it dies not, as human doctrine dies, nor fades as a fragile gift.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:51
verses.text: For no gift of God is fragile.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:52
verses.text: But it remains unchecked, though prophesied as destined to be persecuted to the end.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:53
verses.text: Thus Plato writes of poetry: "A poet is a light and a sacred thing, and cannot write poetry till he be inspired and lose his senses".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:54
verses.text: And Democritus similarly: "Whatever things a poet writes with divine afflatus, and with a sacred spirit, are very beautiful".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book VI 18:55
